name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 6 October 2016 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! As I am sure you all know by now, there was a regrettable incident on Thursday of the last part-session, 6 October, involving two Members of this House. I have asked the Advisory Committee on Members' Code of Conduct to investigate the matter. The Committee, after consulting the members concerned, will make a recommendation on the further procedure. I will inform you about this later this week.  This is the process that you have all seen in the media, in which Mr Woolfe has been dragged into very unpleasantly. I would like to draw your attention at this point to Rule 11(2) of our Rules of Procedure, which states that 'Members' behaviour is characterised by mutual respect'.  I believe that we have all been able to convince ourselves with good reason that, in this case, mutual respect has probably been somewhat neglected and that every Member in this House must adhere to the principles. I also hope that a physical attack on a Member remains an incident that can be described as a one-off derailment. I will inform you of the progress of the matter and of the conclusions of the Advisory Committee.

text: Mr President, I note that on Tuesday we have three votes on the agenda which deal with lifting parliamentary immunity of colleagues: Mr Le Pen, Mr Borghezio and Mrs Collins. These are extremely serious and extremely important decisions. I note, once again, that there are no plans to discuss these issues in plenary. This lack of debate means that it is not even possible to make one's point known through an explanation of oral voting. I consider this to be an extremely regrettable and extremely serious situation which is relatively new. This was not the case in the past in this Parliament, where I have participated in many debates on issues of lifting or maintaining or guaranteeing parliamentary immunity. This reflects, in general, the restrictions on the right and protection of Members for which, I would like to remind you, I have already obtained that the Luxembourg Court of Justice condemns our institution. I got it with regret, but I got it unequivocally in the past.  I would therefore like these issues to be moved to the next session, so that a debate can begin on each of these immunities.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Gollnisch. You are wrong: the procedures for waiving immunities are always the same. The request received here by a Public Prosecutor's Office for the waiver of immunity is announced here in plenary and then referred directly to the Committee on Legal Affairs. That is the first step. The Committee on Legal Affairs shall appoint a rapporteur or rapporteur to examine the dossier. The content and reasons for or against a recommendation by the Committee on Legal Affairs to plenary will be discussed intensively in the relevant committee – that is the Committee on Legal Affairs – on the basis of the rapporteur's recommendations. Then the Committee on Legal Affairs comes to a conclusion, either recommending the waiver or recommending that immunity should not be waived. It is precisely this recommendation that will be voted on without debate here in plenary. This is the normal and normal procedure which, incidentally, applies equally to every Member or Member, irrespective of the person or the group. Wednesday: no change. Thursday: The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance has requested that the item 'changeover between summer and winter time' be moved to the morning on Thursday afternoon and that it be dealt with as the second item on the agenda.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This is, of course, the evergreen at all. We have to comply with firm rules. There are also absolute judgments of the European Court of Justice, which we are bound to upholding. They provide for a clear process. I do it handy. You are absolutely right, Mr Lamberts. Of course, the plenary is sovereign to decide on the agenda as it wants to decide. name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Kaja Kallas on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the legal framework of the European Union in relation to customs infringements and sanctions (COM(2013)0884 – C7-0461/2013 - 2013/0432(COD)) (A8-0239/2016).

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like first to thank all the colleagues, and especially the shadow rapporteurs, who have worked on this file for the very constructive manner in which we have dealt with it.  The Customs Union is not talked about enough but remains one of the successes of the European Union. We should not take it for granted, and we should not think there is no room for improvement. An important piece of the Customs Union is, for instance, missing: we have the same rules but we handle matters in a completely different way when companies or individuals break these common rules.  It might not have been such a big problem before, because some Member States have big ports while some other countries have smaller trade flows and less resources to control. But the modernised Customs Code brought about a trade facilitation measure with the Authorised Economic Operator status, which can be lost if a company commits a serious repeated infringement. A company might lose its status in country A, while still working in country B. This will create distortion of the market and unfair competition. In addition, in the digital age, we have to have the objective of creating new opportunities for small and medium—sized enterprises.  My goal in this report was quite different from the approach taken by the Commission as my focus was on improving compliance businesses with sometimes very complex rules, so that the system leads to fewer infringements and not more. Sanctions are the last resort when there is a lack of compliance, but the starting point cannot be that all companies are intending to break the rules. We need to treat the companies as partners. Circumstances matter and need to be acknowledged. So this has to be taken into account while determining the sanction.  I am really against the strict liability regime that is in place in several countries; it simply deters compliance. A strict liability regime also means that no degree of guilt needs to be determined, which raises a serious question of whether it respects the presumption of innocence. There should be a mix of non-criminal and criminal sanctions when it comes to infringements of customs law and there should be a greater effort by the Member States and the Commission to improve compliance, improve businesses’ knowledge of customs legislation. Last, but not least, it is very important to make sure that the system is fair and proportionate. It is not a fair system if you are a small company trading high—value goods and the sanctions kill your business because of your type of trade. Sanctions need to be about the consequences of the infringement and not strictly about the value of the goods.  I am very happy that Parliament has decided to take this file seriously. It is a very different matter in the Council, where they refuse convergence of a sanction system as a principle. Therefore, I hope that the Council will be a bit more constructive and will decide to work on this important pillar of the Customs Union, that is in compliance with European Union law.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would to thank Mrs Kaja Kallas for her work, and the work of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), on the Commission’s proposal to set up a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions. I am happy to note that the Commission and Parliament share common objectives. These objectives are to ensure a proper enforcement of EU customs law and to provide a level playing field for our economic operators. Since the internal market was set up, EU customs legislation has been fully harmonised in a single legal act. However, the consequences of violating the common rules vary across the Customs Union. They depend on the 28 different legal orders and the administrative or judicial traditions of the Member States. In the absence of a common approach, there is a patchwork of responses to those who break the rules. Currently, Member States have widely different definitions for customs infringements and apply different types and levels of sanctions. Sanctions for certain infringements range from small fines in some Member States to imprisonment in others. The financial threshold for deciding whether an infringement is criminal or not ranges from EUR 266 to EUR 50 000, according to the country where it occurs. National time limits for sanctioning customs offences also vary widely – from one to 30 years – while some Member States have no time limit at all. This results in a lack of legal certainty for businesses, possible competitive distortions in the internal market and unfair advantages for those who breach the law where sanctions are the lowest. This in turn impacts negatively on revenues and the enforcement of policies, such as consumer protection or agriculture, when goods are imported or exported. It also raises questions about the uniformity of the Customs Union, which is a key obligation of the EU as a WTO member. The legislative proposal follows the adoption of the Union’s custom code, which came into force last May and which streamlines and modernises European customs rules and procedures. It is about building a common understanding among all Member States on how customs laws should be enforced. It is about trust and cooperation among EU Member States’ customs administrations with different administrative cultures and legal orders but the same mission. This is why we need an effective, proportionate and decisive system for customs infringements and sanctions in the European Union. For such a system to be efficient and credible, there needs to be a common framework established at EU level. Nevertheless, this is politically sensitive for some Member States, as it touches upon their national competences. Therefore I must express my gratitude to the rapporteur, Mrs Kallas, who, together with the shadow rapporteurs, came up with the proposal for amendments, which in many cases actually improve the text proposed by the Commission. I also understand that the first reading has not yet been completed. I am happy to say that the Commission finds many of the proposed amendments acceptable, although there is certainly room for discussion around the exact wording needed to ensure legal clarity and consistency in this complex field. Nevertheless, there are some issues of concern, and I will briefly mention some of them. For example, in the view of amendments proposed by IMCO to limit the scope of the directive to non-criminal offences, the definition of the scope and the links to criminal law should be further clarified to ensure legal certainty. In addition, this Directive may not be the best instrument to impose reporting obligations on the Commission on aspects of customs enforcement that do not stem from this directive. However, at this stage I wish to reiterate the Commission’s flexibility and availability to discuss the improvements, as long as they maintain the objectives of, and add value to, the proposal. I would like to thank once again Parliament, and especially Mrs Kallas and IMCO, for the constructive approach to the proposal.

name: Franck Proust
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, Commissioner, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade, I am pleased that we have been able to participate in the examination of customs issues usually reserved for the IMCO committee. This approach has been both effective and complementary. It is important to take into account the place of the internal market in a global context, because our partners have already pointed out the inconsistencies in our internal market. We can learn from it. Although the customs union is seen as the backbone of the single market, there is still no integrated approach. Wanting to bring together definitions and penalties for customs offences, what a good idea! Especially in 2016. We should say, "It's about time!"! However, the subject is caught between the exclusive competence of the European Union in customs matters and the principle of subsidiarity of judicial or administrative sanctions of states. This balance must therefore be preserved. However, the lack of vision of some politicians in Europe, which do not understand the issues we face today, is staggering. Only the European Union can develop a common approach to implement customs legislation, mr Magnette says, and perhaps seeks to complicate the facilitation of trade that we are putting in place. More seriously, we need to put in place a great strategy that gives a direction, a course to the economic world of the European Union. This type of initiative is useful in bringing coherence to both the internal market and our foreign trade. Our customs are doing a great job. They must be able to count on a flexible structure and a rigorous framework, which is not uniform in Europe. Let us support this kind of initiative whose objectives of simplification, harmonisation, justice and firmness must be put forward in order to better understand the issues facing the European Union.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I too would, of course, like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent work. I believe that significant improvements have been made to the text that Mrs Kallas has achieved for Parliament in the committee responsible for the Internal Market, in cooperation with Franc Proust from the Committee on International Trade. The principles that Mr Proust has just set out - simplification, harmonisation and less bureaucracy - are principles to which we can fully commit ourselves. What we had to criticise, however, in the Commission's original text was the risk that, in the end, customs legislation would not become a harmonised simplified solution box for entrepreneurs who want to conquer global markets, but a bureaucratic monster that, in the end, significantly increased the risk of criminal sanctions. We have achieved the necessary changes in committee here. I thank everyone for that, and I hope that we can also get a broad majority for this.  Secondly, I believe that it was also important from the point of view of bureaucracy that we were able to agree that minimum penalty limits should not be imposed for minor infringements. In our view, this too is absolutely in line with the WTO decision, which was the basis for the european Commission's drafting and whose need in principle we in Parliament also expressly recognise. With regard to the implementation of the directive on customs infringements and sanctions, we must now bear in mind that the currently very different customs systems in the Member States, the harmonisation of which is in any case due to the continued implementation of the Union Customs Code, can be a hurdle. I would like to take this opportunity to urge the Commission once again to develop an overall strategy in which all Member States also assume their responsibilities in accordance with their customs obligations.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: On behalf of the Group of President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs with whom the work on this issue has been very effective and very fruitful. It was all the more difficult because it was a very technical subject on which compromises were sometimes difficult to achieve, but we really worked in a very constructive frame of mind. I think we can look forward to the result.  We welcomed the Commission's proposal because the customs union is the backbone of the internal market, the other side of the internal market. This is one of the first harmonised policies of the European Union and the adoption of the customs code is a signal of further integration in this area. However, even though it is a very integrated policy of the European Union, inconsistencies remain, particularly with regard to sanctions. Because we are faced with the following paradox: the rules can be the same, but depending on the country in which you carry out your customs procedures, you can, if you break the rules, incur penalties that range from a simple fine in one Member State to a prison sentence in another Member State. It is clear that this situation of inconsistency and disparity leads to opportunities for customs competition between states not at the level of the rules but the sanctions associated with them. Therefore, in order to prevent this circumvention of the common rules of the internal market, which results in several hundred million euros in loss of revenue due to fraud, we believe it is absolutely necessary to harmonize sanctions. In this respect, we have therefore obtained, in my opinion, a very good compromise which avoids this unfair competition between the Member States. We have clarified and strengthened the legal basis. We have clarified definitions, particularly the notions of negligence or the intentional nature of the fault. We have also clarified a number of points on the nature of sanctions. We have ruled out criminal sanctions which remain the exclusive competence of the Member States, which can introduce them if they wish. Finally, we have aligned sanctions and thresholds with the directive on the protection of financial interests in the European Union. This harmonization is, in my view, welcome.  As for the way in which the amount of sanctions is determined, I also think that the compromise we have reached is satisfactory, with a floor for serious offences and a method of calculation based on the amount of duties to ensure proportionality of the penalty. But I think we could have gone a little further on this point, specifying certain criteria to ensure the deterrent side of the instrument.  We also support the possibility of Member States introducing sanctions other than fines, such as suspending the status of an economic operator or revoking an import authorisation.  In addition, the Commission's proposal was reinforced by the introduction of a difference between major and minor infringement, based on objective and contextual factors in order to be able to preserve SMEs, whose infringements would be unintentional due to a lack of knowledge of customs rules. Finally, we welcome the introduction of an amicable settlement procedure and the continuation of the four-year statute of limitations. The harmonisation of customs sanctions is clearly essential to better combat fraud, to better ensure compliance with European rules and also to better feed the EU budget for which tariffs are one of the few resources of their own.   In this context, it is regrettable that the work has not begun in the Council. This dossier is, as such, unfortunately emblematic of the all-too-frequent contradictions between the speech of the Member States, in general, and the positions taken in the Council. In the case of customs sanctions, as in the case of other policies, namely tax or social policies, it is clear that the lack of harmonisation that leads to a situation of competition between states is harmful, undermines the application of common rules and deprives citizens of legitimate resources.  Parliament now has a strong position, a coherent position which I believe is a good basis for work. It is now up to the Council to take responsibility and move forward towards harmonising customs sanctions. I thank the rapporteur and my colleagues again for the excellent work that has been done and I hope that the Council will move quickly on this issue.

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the shadows but also particularly Kaja Kallas for her efforts to try and shape a better and more viable proposal. I know she has put a lot of work in and she has made the proposal better, especially in areas where it was inflexible and legally indefensible, like the presumption of innocence. However, despite her efforts, the ECR cannot support it.  The proposal seeks to do two things. One: to set a common approach for defining what a customs infringement is; two: to set common sanctions for those infringements. Now my Group can see the benefit of a common understanding and the need to reduce the complexity of different customs rules, but we disagree that this necessitates a mandatory set of harmonised Union sanctions.  This is a major infringement on subsidiarity, especially as there is little justification for such a move. I have yet to see a viable reason for the proposal. There is no evidence that importers calculate which Member State is the least onerous in terms of sanctions before they import into it. Even Parliament’s Research Services’ appraisal of the Commission impact assessment was unable to find any evidence of this.  However, when we look at the details of the proposal they are even more problematic. The Commission wants to treat a small or medium-sized company, or a home business, with no experience of customs rules, that accidently infringes those rules just as harshly as a multinational corporation with decades of knowledge and hundreds of staff. That is wrong. It risks killing the rapidly growing online cross-border trade and runs directly contrary to the Commission’s aims in creating the digital single market.  At its heart, the original proposal was too prescriptive and inflexible, giving customs regimes no room to use common sense and to examine intent and capabilities when assessing infringement. This should be up to the Member States. Now on customs sanctions, my Group cannot therefore agree with the rapporteur where she has gone beyond the Commission in some respects, particularly in Articles 11 and 12, with specific figures for specific infringements.  However, to conclude: greater consistency of custom rules for ease of trade, yes; prescriptive one-size-fits-all sanctions that infringe national sovereignty and Member States’ legal systems and risk killing the digital single market, no, and therefore the ECR Group cannot support it.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, thank you all for their very constructive cooperation on this important issue. I welcome the Commission's attempt to address the weakness of our single customs territory, namely the customs offences detected and the resulting penalties. Penalties for infringements were left in the hands of the legislators of the nation states in customs legislation and, unfortunately, it has led to varying punitive practices in different EU countries also attracting companies to customs shopping, then distorting the market to the loss of well- and lawfully managed companies.  When there is a common way of interpreting what a customs infringement is, as well as a uniform penal penalty procedure, I believe that it will increase the transparency and efficiency of imports and exports, including in the European Union, and put companies of all sizes a little better on the same footing. We also need a fair playing field on this customs issue, and I am particularly much in favour of it. I like the fact that the rapporteur has put a great deal of effort into finding similar solutions.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is the point of living in a community if the rules are not the same for everyone? The European Union is also a customs union: there are no borders between countries, only external borders, so goods entering Romanian customs arrive without controls on the Italian market and vice versa. That is why it is important for European customs to apply similar procedures, controls and sanctions. Parliament is about to adopt by a large majority a directive to harmonise precisely the framework for customs sanctions.  At present, those who do not comply with the rules have to pay a fine and if this fine varies depending on the country, of course, they will let in the goods where they pay the least in case they are "pinched". Sanctions must therefore be harmonised: Parliament is almost unanimous in this, but some Eastern European states led by Germany and the Netherlands are blocking them because they do not intend to change things, or rather, because they do not want to change.  However, the issue of customs is not just a question of sanctions, controls and procedures should also be harmonised, which is why I will be rapporteur in the INTA Committee for a great process of reflection on the future of European customs, and I believe that the unblocking of this dossier is essential if we are to be able to continue. Frankly, I have grown tired, and like me I believe many, many citizens, of a Europe where everyone eats, but only someone pays the bill. A Europe of solidarity only when it suits it: economy, immigration, taxation and now customs. It is time to put an stop to those who use the Union solely for their own interests.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this directive aims to establish a common legal framework for the Member States of the European Union in order to eliminate the disparities between the different national regimes that are applied. In other words, it is a matter of harmonizing the national applications of customs legislation in order to complete the implementation of the customs union. National disparities in the implementation of this customs union do have an impact on the equality of the conditions of competition, in that they provide an advantage to those who do not comply with the law in a Member State whose customs sanctions regime is more lenient. The risk to offenders is therefore not the same depending on the door to the single internal market.  These distortions of competition are factually commonplace within this single internal market, whether social, environmental, financial, economic or political in nature. The French make it the bitter experience every day. In short, the scheme is simple. Member States continue to transpose EU directives into national laws according to their own interests. While I see it as a patriotic act, the rapporteur explains that some Member States are dragging their feet. For the Commission and the European institutions, on the other hand, it is mortal sin. On the contrary, we need more Europe.  Despite the economic crisis in the euro area, the amplification of the migration crisis, the obvious rejection of this conception of European integration by the peoples of Europe, as evidenced by Brexit or Belgium's rejection of CETA, the Juncker Commission is still advocating more and more integration. As the proverb errare humanum is, perseverare diabolicum, error is human, stubbornness is diabolical. This chimerical project of a homogeneous harmonised single market is shattered by economic, political, geographical and therefore national realities. I think this is great news for the future.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As my colleague Virginie Roziére said a while ago, this draft report that has been made is a good basis for further work, and I also appreciate Mrs Kallas' work in this area. It seems to be something technical, but it has very far-reaching political statements that are also associated with it. And indeed, we have an internal market. Customs law is a European competence, and yet we still have small-scale government in this area. This is something that is actually intolerable. That is why it is right and proper that the European Commission has given us the opportunity to ensure that common definitions are finally created and that common standards are also set in the area of sanctions and in action in these areas. This is absolutely necessary if we want to ensure that there is not a patchwork of regulations, particularly as regards sanctions, as before, and that companies, which do not have the right to be the top principle, are given the opportunity to do forum shopping – to choose the state in which it is easiest to enforce abuses. That is something that is intolerable. That is why I say to those Members who have said that we should now have subsidiarity: that is wrong, quite simply wrong. We must create common rules so that this internal market is actually an internal market and the external borders are also common external borders and the market, the trade that we have with the outside world, is also a common market, so that we in the European Union can really make the best possible contribution to this and say no to small-scale government.  I would like to make it quite clear to the Member States: please stop it, but sit down and ensure that we really shape a common policy, including in this area.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, Britain and other nations suffer from the restrictions imposed by the Customs Union. As a member in our current standing Britain is unable to make its own trade deals and has to rely on unelected bureaucrats to negotiate on behalf of the whole of Europe. Just look at how this has worked out. TTIP is over, and CETA is on the rocks, with years and years of negotiating and nothing to show for it. Yet we hear scare stories from some who seem willing to make economic sacrifices to spite the will of the British people. May I remind those people that the impact which this could have on the EU and its businesses is enormous. In fact, experts have said that a failure by the EU to successfully negotiate a free trade deal with Britain could cost European Union exporters up to 13 billion a year.  Amongst the doom and gloom, however, is an exciting future for Britain. Since the vote our government has begun informal trade talks with prospering nations from around the world including Australia, New Zealand, India and many many more. This is Britain’s chance to set a future precedent for other nations who are also considering leaving the European Union – free trade, cooperation without the necessity of a political union.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Firstly, I would like to congratulate the reporter, because he has had a very good approach to the subject and has also made a very good proposal, which could be a very good starting point for our joint future cooperation, i.e. cooperation between Member States. Everyone is talking – and I absolutely agree, my starting point – that, in order to protect the internal market, it is essential that action must be taken whenever our customs rules, our common rules, are violated. This is what the common protection of our financial interests requires, and that is what cooperation requires.  At the same time, there is a very diverse, I would say, very colourful picture of the procedural practices of the Member States, which is not right. I believe that this palette, it is so wide and gives the possibility of fraud, that it must be narrowed down in any way. I can absolutely support the harmonised system, the design of the one that is capable of reducing red tape, is capable of being much better aligned in this system, and it is also capable of distinguishing between accidentally violating the law or knowingly and serially doing so. It would also be good to know whether this will mean a single penalty in the Member States. I congratulate the reporter and, of course, I will support the report.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, the primary objective of this directive is the harmonisation at European Union level of the different national rules relating to infringements and subsequent customs penalties. The ineffectiveness of customs controls at key entry points of the single market is now conducive to the movement of non-law-compliant goods throughout the Union. Some of Europe's important seaports are, for example, too easy a landing place for counterfeit goods. The creation of a genuine customs union is hampered by the fragmentation and heterogeneity of rules and standards that prevent the proper functioning of the European single market and put citizens and consumers at risk. In this respect, we welcome the fact that the determination of penalties is linked, where possible, to the principle of the duty evaded to ensure greater correspondence with the seriousness of the infringement. The future of the European economy will depend very much on how our continent manages to establish trade relations with other parts of the world. All this presupposes, however, a legal framework that is fully complementary to the principles and best practices of the WTO which, on the one hand, facilitates trade with third countries and, on the other, guarantees the repression of all those illegal activities that endanger our security and competitiveness.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am not in support of unnecessary legislation adopted by the EU. I stand by the principle of subsidiarity, but I must say that in this case I believe that the adoption of legislation makes sense.  At a time when we have a single customs territory, where there is a single customs substantive law, where the Customs Code applies here, then, in my opinion, it makes sense that there should also be one adjustment to the sanctions that will apply throughout the EU. In short, a specific offence should be the same sanction throughout the EU, if possible. It is a fundamental principle of the rule of law. There should be a similar penalty for a similar offence. So that is why I support the amendment, why I agree with the idea, even though I am generally reticent about new European legislation. If we look at the concrete implementation, then I must say that the proposal put forward by the Commission is unfortunately not very good, and here, like my pre-chairmen, I commend the work of the IMCO rapporteur in particular, who I think has been able to eliminate a number of legal problems. I agree with the text that came out of the IMCO committee. At least one thing: the sanction is to be imposed for misconduct, the objective liability that was in the commission's original proposal is, in my view, absolutely unacceptable and has significantly harmed entrepreneurs. So perhaps, Commissioner, it would like better legislation in the future, which you are proposing here.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I want to begin by congratulating the rapporteur and rapporteurs in the shadows and, of course, also the position of the colleagues who have spoken. I do not think that we can talk about a customs union when we have fully harmonised legislation throughout the European Union, but the application and, whatever, the verification of compliance with customs rules and the imposition of sanctions is a matter for each state. And we now know concretely that we have differences - and big differences, not very small. This, in my view, disadvantages the small ones, small and medium-sized enterprises, first and foremost. The same formalities, the same documents are completed, the economic operator must take the same steps, but when it goes through one customs or another, the penalty is different if at a check things are not right. That is why I support the principle of taking action aimed at leading to a certain level of alignment in the twenty-eight States, because that is why we have a single market, to have procedures, sure, national, but to harmonise the level of penalties for customs infringements.  I believe that this provides legal certainty for businesses and could create a fairer conditions that encourage businesses, especially SMEs, to invest in all Member States and stimulate economic growth. Personally, I have also made amendments, and I hope that this report will be voted on and we will take steps, because I do not think that we are finishing with the customs union alone with this report. And I also believe, at the same time, that the Member States must, and it is also the role of the Commission, adopt greater transparency and see better application of customs legislation. After all, we must all move towards measures that improve and comply with customs legislation, but not encourage the passage of certain borders just because the sanctions are lower. I support the report and congratulate Mrs Callas.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as we know, the aim of this proposal was to harmonise the approach to the enforcement of customs legislation and particularly to sanctions for infringements. At the moment, customs rules across the EU are the same under the Union’s Customs Code, but when those rules are infringed, enforcement follows 28 different sets of legal rules and administrative traditions. That creates inconsistency within Member States and can generate uncertainty for businesses. I am happy with the text that we are going to vote on this week. First of all, there will be no fixed minimum sanction for minor infringements, and secondly, for both minor and serious infringements, the financial fine should be imposed as a percentage of the duties evaded. The report also allows for the possibility, where the nature and the gravity of infringements so require, for Member States to impose criminal sanctions in accordance with national laws instead of non-criminal sanctions as provided for by the directive . I believe that with this text we are ready for further negotiations with the Council and the Commission.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important that there is so much sharing, as the Commissioner has heard, on the issue we are discussing, because I believe that the Customs Union is objectively a pillar of the single market.  At other times and for other measures, we are debating the importance of giving this part of the world rules that are convergent, overcoming the differences that have historically been made up to the present day in each individual country and, above all, we are trying to make visible an idea of the European Union in which diversity is overcome. One of the most serious and dangerous differences is precisely that, which still remains, but which we are trying to overcome, of the differences in the detection of customs infringements and then of the sanctions that each country decides to apply as it wishes. The progress we are proposing is therefore extremely important.  I would like to point out that sanctions have two positive effects. The first is the ethical one: those who make mistakes have to pay and have to pay in proportion to the mistake they make or the violation that they skilfully put in place. On the other hand, the sanction has a deterrent value: those who are oriented to hurt know that they have to pay, for this reason the direction sometimes changes. One final point: we must act quickly. The current situation is such that it leads to distortions of competition, just like the lack of uniform behaviour in tax matters.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, although the customs union is considered to be one of the foundations of the European Union, as well as the pillar of the single market, there is still no integrated approach to the application of customs legislation, including sanctions. At present, in fact, there are also significant breaches in the application of sanctions within the single market.  The establishment of a legal framework for customs infringements and sanctions is essential to improve the convergence of Member States' approaches to the application of EU customs legislation. However, much will depend on how the Member States interpret the directive. Real-time monitoring of compliance with standards through information technology requires close cooperation between operators to ensure full compliance, as well as the implementation by Member States of the provisions on electronic systems contained in the Union Customs Code. Member States must respect their commitment to take part in a common risk management system.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the way customs authorities operate and control is an important factor for the smooth functioning of a State and the proper functioning of the internal market. The Member States of the Union must do their duty and combat fraud in the customs field, thereby contributing to the achievement of the objective of the internal market for the disposal of safe products with genuine certificates of origin and the fight against dumping and the search for more favourable jurisdiction.  There are not a few times in which we have seen products being bapted domestically and circulating heathlonly on national markets. In Greece there have been too many cases of illegal Greekization of products, which now cross the border, are baptized Greek, so that greek farmers already impoverished by the memorandum see their own products rot. The greekizations of lambs from Skopje are known every year, as well as it is known that oil from Tunisia is baptized Greek. Measures are therefore needed to stop these illegalities.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would of course like to support the report of my colleague, Mrs Kallas, right from the start. Convinced that, having observed this absurdity in her report, that we have a common customs code, but that at the same time each state sanctions violators on its own, i.e. has its own sanctions, 28 different legislatures in this regard. I am definitely sure that the single customs market and this part is a great success of the European Union and is recognized for that. That's why I support it to the maximum.  What I want to emphasize further, which of course in this report is not visible, is the need to try to overcome the problems we will face with the enlargement of the European Union in southeast Europe. So, I call for this to be included in the report and to discuss how to negotiate with countries that will join the European Union in five, seven, 10 years and to try to do everything in these negotiations to have no further trouble in terms of the diversity of legislatures.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, following the implementation of the Schengen Treaty and on the basis of the founding act of the Union as the European Economic Community, cross-border trade still faces the distortions of a complex customs legislation mechanism. Twenty-eight different Member States apply rigour as they see fit and impose different sanctions. However, this has a direct impact on cross-border trade, resulting in a loss of revenue from the Member States. This phenomenon is particularly noticeable in countries where products from outside the Union are imported and subsequently transported to the rest of Europe across the borders of Member States. The Union has failed the examinations on major issues: the economy, cross-border trade, illegal immigration, counter-terrorism. Member States, with nationalist governments ensuring their national borders free from ideologies and anchorages, will be able to work together to increase the effectiveness of customs controls on goods and to crack down on revenue evasion.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate. The Commission remains open to further work on this directive and to clarify the points where necessary. I think today’s debate clearly showed that the European Commission and Parliament share the same objectives to have a level playing field and to ensure uniform application of EU Customs Code.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the colleagues who spoke on this matter. I agree with Mr Proust and Mr Schwab that we need a clear vision from the Commission: a strategy that includes the single market, the Customs Union and trade policy. In a world where everything is moving to be digital, it is very important that we make the rules very simple. We should also make sure that the authorities act as partners to the micro-businesses and not as obstacles. On the inter-link between the administrative and criminal sanctions, the Commission wants to have more clarity. However, I point out that in the Commission’s proposal the Member States could do whatever they wanted, so that was not clear either. In my report we do clarify that we need a harmonised approach towards the non-criminal sanctions, and we only leave room for the criminal sanctions if they need to be dissuasive. We certainly need to support the Commission in the discussions with the Council to ensure that the criminal sanctions are not used for anything else than serious infringements. Regarding the ECR’s comments: they raised the issue that the bureaucracy is a problem. Of course we agree, but don’t you think that having 28 sets of different rules is a bigger problem for the micro-businesses than to have one set of rules? We definitely want to diminish the bureaucracy here. Finally, I really ask the Council to do some work on this file, as we have addressed very many issues that were Member States’ concerns in this report: for example, the strict liability issue. So the ball is in the Council’s court.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 25 October 2016.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Richard Howitt, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU strategy for Iran following the nuclear agreement (2015/2274(INI) (A7-0286/2016).

name: Richard Howitt
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the Iran Nuclear Agreement was a big achievement for European and international diplomacy. It is an important signal that nuclear non-proliferation is possible in our world. The EU strategy which followed, fully supported by my report, is about Europe fully upholding our obligations under that agreement. To do so, I support the opening of an EU delegation in Tehran and cooperation on maritime security in the Persian Gulf as a concrete step towards a new regional security structure for the whole region; setting the aim for a partnership and cooperation agreement for a bilateral investment treaty and of Iran joining the World Trade Organisation. Supporting the major deal for Airbus and efforts for banks themselves to support the lifting of sanctions; to restore our own interparliamentary dialogue with the Majlis. Colleagues, this is a balanced and inclusive report incorporating 22 compromise paragraphs from no less than 139 amendments from different Members of this Parliament. I thank the shadows, and Mr Brok in particular, for their cooperation.  On human rights: the human rights NGO Reprieve called the language of my report ‘excellent’. Human Rights Watch said: it is ‘good language’. The words ‘human rights’ actually appears 34 times in my report. By focusing on ending the death penalty for children and for all drug offenses I am supporting efforts which are already under way in Iranian society itself and that I dearly hope will actually be agreed. Those who say that my report ‘is not human rights enough’ simply impugn my own integrity and contradict the human rights organisations themselves. They knowingly imperil the leverage that we do have with Iran and make the improvements in human rights, which they say you want, less, not more, likely. They should examine your own conscience before you repeat that claim.  My report clearly called for non-interference in other countries and an end to support for armed groups. It specifically supports respect for peace and security for Israel and for Palestinians. It suggests that Europe can play a greater role in de-escalating tension between Tehran and Riyadh, and that this is the essential part of bringing to an end the terrible conflicts which afflict Iran’s neighbours. There are those in this Chamber who want greater one-sided criticism of Iran’s regional role. They say they are against proxy wars but you yourselves are acting as proxies; don’t do it. For those that are using this debate to wage these arguments, but who do so actually seeking to oppose the nuclear agreement: be honest in saying so. I will be honest with you about the consequences of the agreement’s collapse: a nuclear arms race in the Middle East, heightened security fears, undermining reformists and shifting power to hardliners here and there, a return to sanctions in which ordinary innocent people in Iran are impoverished and lose hope, a potentially fatal attack on diplomatic attempts to end suffering, death and destruction in the bloody civil wars in Syria and in Yemen. Indeed, an attack on the very principle that diplomacy and negotiated agreement itself could be successful in our troubled world. My report stands for peace, an active diplomatic role for Europe, and a belief that by identifying common interest where it exists, that it is possible to build on it. I ask for your support.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am honoured to be here today and thank you for the opportunity to discuss Iran this evening. This is a timely debate falling almost precisely on the first anniversary of the adoption of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), which took place on 18 October 2015. It is important to recall that day, because it was one of the milestones of the nuclear agreement and an important step in restoring trust with Iran. The implementation day which occurred a few days later, after the IAEA confirmed Iran’s compliance with its nuclear commitments, triggered the lifting of sanctions and effectively opened up the possibility to begin a new chapter in our bilateral relations. In this context, I thank Mr Richard Howitt for his work on the report on the EU strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement, which I see as a valuable contribution in this latest stage of the European Union’s relations with Iran. This Parliament has shown a strong interest and active support throughout the negotiations of the nuclear deal with Iran. Today, one year after the JCPOA was adopted, I also welcome the broad support you are giving to our policy of balance and incremental engagement with Iran. We believe that this approach reflects the new state of European Union-Iran relations after the nuclear deal, as the title of Parliament’s report that will be voted on tomorrow aptly points out. The European Union has played a crucial role in the context of the JCPOA. We were perceived by all sides as an honest broker throughout the whole of the negotiations, and the High Representative and her representatives were entrusted with the role of coordinator of the Joint Commission which today oversees the implementation of the agreement. This is of value in itself, and we need to fulfil this role effectively, because our interests are also at stake, in particular the sustainability of the JCPOA. Sustainability is crucial for the deal to hold, but sustainability can only be ensured if all sides properly implement the JCPOA and if the Iranian people, who strongly backed the deal, can feel its economic benefits and reconnect with the international community. The good news is that the implementation is on track. Iran has been delivering on its nuclear commitments and, since implementation day, the IAEA has issued three positive reports confirming this. But as I said, sustainability requires firm and longstanding adherence throughout the lifetime of the agreement. The European Union has delivered on all its commitments. We have lifted the agreed economic and financial nuclear-related sanctions. We have gone beyond that and conducted an extensive outreach to our economic operators, informing them about and clarifying the new regulatory framework. The initial reluctance by the financial and banking sector and wider business community to re—engage is a natural phenomenon, given that companies need to feel comfortable and confident to come back and invest in Iran again. The remaining United States primary sanctions – and we had a debate on this in July – and the poor business environment in Iran, are additional factors for hesitation. Iran also needs to do its part in terms of increasing transparency in its financial system and improving its efforts as regards anti-money laundering and counter—financing of terrorism framework and institutions. Iran’s commitment to take the necessary measures to comply with the Action Plan or the Financial Action Task Force is a step in the right direction. The European Union stands ready to share expertise with the Iranian authorities on this matter. The nuclear deal has opened the door for renewed bilateral European Union-Iran cooperation. In fact we are already using the opportunities and have started working together in some areas of mutual interest. Commissioner Stylianides is in Iran, as we speak, to address the issue of Afghan refugees and access to humanitarian relief in the countries of the region affected by conflict. Commissioner Bieńkowska was in Tehran last week with European Union business representatives and launched a European Union-Iran industrial dialogue. Just a few weeks ago, we received a high-level visit from Iran on the environment, and we agreed to launch cooperation on environmental protection. I know these are important issues for some of you. On trade-related issues, our commercial exchanges went up by 42%, compared with the same period last year. And we have also been supportive of Iran’s accession to the WTO, because we see a clear advantage in having Iran playing along with internationally-agreed rules. The European Union has established cooperation also in other areas such as energy and nuclear safety, but also in education, culture and research. Indeed, our engagement allows us to foster people-to-people contacts. The young people of Iran are Iran’s wealth, and investing in them means investing in the future of the country. We have therefore increased exchanges of students through Erasmus+ and of scientists and researchers in Horizon 2020. Let me stress again that, while we proceed with this level of engagement, we do not lose sight of the issues where we do not see eye to eye. On the contrary, engagement in areas of mutual interest allows us to open channels of communication to address areas where we have differences. Human rights remain an obvious area of concern. The high number of executions and the restrictions to civil freedoms are worrying, and regular public statements are released in this respect. This is why when we negotiated a joint statement with Iran on the future of our relations, adopted last April during the visit of the High Representative to Iran, we said very clearly that human rights have to be an integral part of it, and this is materialising. A dedicated delegation from the Iranian judiciary system will come to Brussels in early November, in the framework of the political dialogue, to hold exploratory talks on human rights. This will happen for the first time in more than 10 years. We also have differences with Iran on some regional issues where Iran’s behaviour has not changed and remains problematic. We have been clear in calling for tangible steps that can lead to more constructive regional relations, in particular in the case of Syria. High Representative Mogherini has been in regular touch with Foreign Minister Zarif on the European Union’s humanitarian initiative and with a view to laying the ground for the resumption of an inclusive and Syrian-led political process under the auspices of the United Nations.  At the same time, we need to be aware of the domestic and political scene in Iran. The situation remains polarised, and a return to a period of confrontation with the international community is still favoured by some forces. Parliament’s report on the European Union strategy towards Iran after the nuclear deal also needs to be seen in this light. It should be a contribution to our renewed balanced engagement. I should not end without mentioning the important role that parliamentary contacts can play in fostering closer relations and conveying a message on these different issues. We now have a new Majlis in Iran after the February parliamentary elections. Engagement with parliamentarians is an important complement to the official diplomatic channels. When the High Representative visited Iran in April with a group of Commissioners, she framed our future relation as the ‘Four Cs’ dialogue: comprehensive in scope; cooperative where there is mutual interest; critical when we disagree, but constructive in nature. I am glad that the current text of the European Parliament resolution is endorsing this approach. I can only reiterate our willingness to continue working closely with you towards this goal in respect of the different mandate and functions of the institution.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Madam President, together with shadow rapporteurs from the Committee on International Trade – and I would like to thank them – we focused on the trade and investment aspects of EU-Iran relations one year after the important JCPOA, otherwise known as the Iran Nuclear Deal, which of course must be implemented. Since then, several delegations travelled to Iran to explore the potential, which in theory is huge. But both the Iranian people and EU companies learned that doing business, in practice, in Iran is not only a matter of lifting sanctions, and it is not as easy as it seems. The high levels of corruption, the grey economy, as well as terror financing but also the lack of a truly private sector, with up to 70% state-controlled, make it difficult to do business, and trade and investment must of course be done according to the law and benefit the population, which has suffered enough and continues to suffer. The human capital is Iran’s most valuable asset, so imagine what is possible when development goes hand in hand with human rights and fundamental freedoms, when labour rights are improved – including for women – and when environmental protection is upgraded. We must bring Iran under the rules-based system according to the Financial Action Task Force against money laundering and where possible explore the WTO path.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Thank you very much for the opportunity to say a few words on my group. The main reason for this agreement is that it does not have any more nuclear-weapon states. I believe that this has been achieved, and the European Union, with Federica Mogherini and Helga Schmid, in particular has played a major role in ensuring that this has been achieved. The entire world community wants this agreement. The United Nations Security Council unanimously supported this. We should integrate into the world community on this issue so that the Non-Proliferation Pact really has credibility. If Iran gets nuclear weapons, there will be no stopping. That, I believe, is our ultimate responsibility. Moreover, this treaty can be terminated if Iran does not comply with the rules, and sanctions can be reintroduced. All of this is regulated by the Treaty, so we do not need to worry about that either. Of course, it is important that Iran also fulfils certain conditions over time. That is why I am Mr Howitt – for whom this is obviously the last report in this House because he is leaving the House. I regret that you made your decision in this way. I would have liked to continue working with you. – grateful that this report, certainly after long debates between the political groups, has now included the issues of human rights, the issues of unacceptable death, the issues of arrests, which take place for political and other reasons, the disadvantage of religious minorities. It has also been made clear that we are calling on Iran and Saudi Arabia to stop their proxy war and not to promote terrorist organisations – Hezbollah has been specifically mentioned – and also to stop the financial cycles in this area accordingly. I think it is important that it should also be made clear on this issue that Israel's security is an essential issue for us. This can certainly be strengthened. In any case, this is an important point that makes it clear that we are not abandoning our values. We do not want nuclear weapons. That's why the deal is important. We want to take advantage of the economic opportunities of this agreement, and that is what we want to work on. There are still many drawbacks that Mrs Schaake has mentioned. We should now express the question of our fight against terror, for human rights, for the death penalty, for religious minorities. That is what this report does, and that is why my group will support this report.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, a year ago I was very glad to see a breakthrough in the Iranian nuclear deal. The EU played an important role in this success. I trust the deal can be beneficial for all parties involved. This is significant progress for the security, stability and development of the entire region, but it still remains extremely important for it to be implemented thoroughly and in good faith by all partners as soon as possible. We should not forget that this deal goes beyond its technical details. It has already been celebrated by the Iranian people, who consider that this could represent a step forward in improving their living standards. It is essential for both sides to deliver on that. Only a successful implementation will allow us to show the benefits of multilateral diplomacy over the policy of obstructionism and confrontation. One of our main worries is the fact that, in spite of the partial lifting of sanctions, EU companies are still facing great difficulty in accessing the Iranian market. This is mostly due to the fact that many American financial sanctions are still in place and have an extraterritorial impact. As far as I am aware of them, I share some of the concerns of my colleagues towards Iran, notably the ones linked to the use of ballistic missiles and human rights abuses and violations, including the use of the death penalty in Iran. It is important to use all channels, in cooperation with the United States, to find and address at least a temporary solution to the difficulties faced by our companies. It is important to engage Iran in order to work together towards improving the environment for human rights and equally to win more regional stability and prosperity. Having said this, I will conclude with an important call on Iran to stop its interference in other countries in the region and to refrain from supporting armed groups, in particular its support for the Syrian regime, Hamas, al-Nusra and Hezbollah, and to play a more positive and constructive role in bringing back peace to the Middle East.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, reaching an agreement with Iran last summer regarding its nuclear ambitions was a major diplomatic success for the European Union and US foreign—policy interests. The combined sanctions regime proved very effective in putting pressure on the economy and resulted in bringing the Tehran regime, and its electorate, to the conclusion that the country needed to reform and a government that was willing to be able to engage with the West and negotiate a deal. The Iranian Government is not one that we in Europe share common values with. I too condemn its atrocious human rights abuses, including internationally banned juvenile executions, its sectarian politics, its development of a ballistic missile system, its interventionist regional policies in Syria, Yemen, Bahrain and Lebanon that are often counterproductive. These are differences that we should and will continue to voice our disapproval of and to argue that the peoples of Iran deserve and are capable of better. Such concerns, however, should not dictate a policy of total disengagement. The negotiations were a final attempt to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, and in turn hastening an inevitable nuclear arms race in the Persian Gulf region, without the use of force. Many have argued that a military solution was, and remains, the one and only solution in the long term. The military experts have made it clear that such a policy would be hugely difficult to achieve without paying a huge personal price. This is nothing to say of the subsequent fallout which, I have no doubt, would be very damaging politically in an already volatile region. This deal is only welcomed as a pragmatic one and its rejection would play right into the hands of regime hardliners. It does not mean that we have reached the end of the road. Close scrutiny that the terms are being adhered to and the will to reimpose sanctions at the slightest of violations are of utmost importance. It is unknown where this deal will take us over the next decade but I personally remain hopeful that it can build trust and allow time for a new political landscape to develop from that ancient Persian culture and to emerge from that. I too would like to take this opportunity to extend my thanks to Richard Howitt. We come from very different political families, we have disagreed on many things, Richard, over many years, but I too would like to wish you luck in the next chapter of your life.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it has been over a year since the nuclear deal was concluded, but of course it is better late than never to have the European Parliament’s opinion as well.  Our Group welcomes the successful lead by the High Representative/Vice President and her team – consisting mostly of females – and the success of EU common diplomacy and international cooperation at times when this is more necessary but most rare. I have shared my thoughts on trade and investment and the possibilities offered when the deal is implemented. So now let us focus with equal resolve on the many remaining problems in our relationship: human rights and fundamental freedoms, from the high levels of executions – even of minors – to the torture in Iran’s notorious prisons. Witness the lack of a fair trial for suspects and the general absence of equal rights for women, ethnic and religious minorities, and LGTBIs – and the list goes on, extending to the lack of free expression for journalists, academics, artists, people in general and politicians with critical views. Instead of making the lives of Iranian people better, the regime spends billions on supporting the Assad regime in its cowardice, murder and bombing of innocent people.  Focusing on our shared objective of fighting Daesh cannot hide the real differences between us. The EU lists the military wing of Hezbollah as a terror group; Iran supports it.  President, excuse me, it’s my understanding that I have 2.5 minutes. Am I wrong?  Thank you, President.  The EU lists the military wing of Hezbollah as a terror group. Iran supports it. The emphasis on these key topics was lacking in the report, and we found it important to strongly and unequivocally condemn human rights violations and the damaging role that the Islamic Republic plays in the region.  Now this is not, Mr Howitt, an attack on the nuclear deal, its implementation or you personally. It is merely a matter of differences of opinion and priorities, which I think is entirely normal in a democracy.  My Group calls on Iran to be a part of the solution to the war in Syria and – as we are also asking of Saudi Arabia – to halt interference in the affairs of neighbouring partners,  recognise Israel and stop denying the Holocaust. We should work together where possible on the basis of clear benchmarks, and we need an EU delegation on the ground.  Our Group sees opportunity to cooperate on environmental protection, on which what little civil society remains in Iran is bravely pushing for more action. We believe that people-to-people contact through exchanges is key, but people must be able to return safely to Iran when they have dual nationality. People-to-people connections also take place online. Therefore, the emergence of a free and open Internet in Iran, one that is not nationally and centrally monitored and censored, is key for young people likewise to come out of isolation.  I want to stress that it is time for a real step out of the dark, out of isolation, and that includes free and fair elections. Our Group seeks to balance this report and hopes that our key amendments will be adopted: otherwise, unfortunately, we will not be able to support this resolution.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last year's agreement and the lifting of sanctions on its nuclear programme have removed Iran from the isolation imposed on it by the West. We expect Iran to make constructive use of its important role, not only in the Middle East but globally, contributing to peace, stability and development. In this respect, Iran's involvement in resolving conflicts and political crises is necessary and constantly judged.  The European Union must develop with Iran an open, honest, ambitious, multi-level, cross-sectoral dialogue in a climate of building mutual trust and respect, on the basis of an assessment of common interests and differences, in a way that benefits both the Iranian people and the peoples of Europe. In this debate we have a duty as MEPs to make an active contribution, and not only in the narrow parliamentary framework. We have a duty to put at the heart of our dialogue and cooperation issues relating to the security and well-being of our peoples, to deepen an honest and productive dialogue on human rights, to support efforts for greater control over arms trafficking, legal and non-legal, in order to put an end to the increasing militarisation of the region. We have a duty to expand our cooperation in all areas: culture, education, trade, energy, environmental sustainability. Multi-level cooperation based on mutual respect for international standards and principles.  Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we must put pressure on our partners, the United States, to lift unilateral primary sanctions against the Iranian people. Not only because they strangle European companies that want to invest in Iran, but first and foremost for the negative impact they have on human rights and in particular on the right of the Iranian people to food, health and development.  Personally, I believe that today's report is balanced and responds to most of the challenges to further developing our relations with Iran, and mr Howitt has of course made a very positive contribution to this.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This report is an expression of the European Union's desire to cooperate with the Islamic Republic of Iran. The report is a U-turn in politics: away from a policy of isolation, towards a policy of dialogue and rapprochement. The nuclear agreement is a glimmer of hope for many Iranians who are eagerly awaiting the opening of their country and, above all, for an improvement in their social, social and economic situation.  I should simply remind you that there is high unemployment in Iran and that parts of the population are living in a very poor economic situation. It is often said to me that improving these things is the sole responsibility of the respective governments. I do not have this opinion, because we know from our own history that political dialogue and the resulting practical and economic cooperation can deliver much better results than a policy of isolation. The Iranian Government has shown, by concluding and complying with this agreement, that it is willing to cooperate with us. As it turned out in a conversation with the Deputy Foreign Minister, it has taken Iran a great deal of overcoming to accept those parts of the nuclear treaty that do not relate to the military use of nuclear energy, but to commercial use. Here, too, the Iranian Government has given in and complied with our demands.  Now it is our turn. We must recognise and promote what is reflected in Iran in positive and somewhat more liberal development. Nevertheless, it is clear that we are far from having ideal conditions in Iran itself. That is why the report has a whole series of demands which are very clear, very clear. I would just like to pick out some of the things that are particularly important to me personally.  We call for the release as soon as possible of all political prisoners, especially, of course, those who have dual citizenship. We call for respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and, above all, for international labour, social and environmental standards. This is something that social standards in particular are often not respected, which must be emphasised. We call on the Iranian judiciary to ensure the right to fair and due trial. We call for environmental protection and the promotion of environmentally sustainable development, including, if possible, European cooperation. In this context, I would like to draw attention to the environmental disaster around Lake Urmia, a disaster that has an impact far beyond Iran's borders. Then, as has been mentioned many times, we call on Iran to introduce a moratorium on the death penalty. Iran is the country with the highest rate of executions in the world, in terms of population.  I believe that the report is a step in the right direction, that it can achieve a great deal of improvement, and I therefore hope that it will be adopted tomorrow by a large majority.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the Iranian nuclear agreement represented possibly one of the biggest shifts in Western—Middle Eastern relations for decades. Whilst the full repercussions of the nuclear agreement, as well as whether all sides can stick to it, remain to be seen, what is beyond doubt is that the agreement gives us further grounds to continue dialogue and continue building up mutual trust and respect.  If this is to prove fruitful, it must be done through existing international institutions and multilateral and bilateral dialogue. In this report, however, I must especially  question its aim of an EU strategy. Once again the EU is showing its immaturity when it comes to diplomacy. I believe that the too much, too quickly approach taken in this report may actually prove to be counterproductive in the long term. As we all know, trust can take decades to build but be broken far more quickly.  I believe that the comments in this report on Syria are pointless. Middle Eastern diplomacy is – to make an obvious understatement – complex, with the multifaceted interests of major players globally and regionally. All parties represent legitimate national concerns, and it is only by coming to a reasonable accommodation that a lasting peace can be found. In short, I would suggest that we build slowly on the success of the dialogue before the nuclear deal. Let us agree where we can agree and agree to discuss differences where we can. However, whilst my own concerns over the Iranian stance towards Israel remain relevant and topical in this context, let us not pressure Iran with an all-encompassing agreement that we know would be doomed to failure. For once let us stop posturing and see if we can actually bring some stability to the region. I would also like to pay tribute to Richard. Richard, you and I disagree on pretty much everything, but I think that the Foreign Affairs Committee will be a different place without you, certainly from a British viewpoint. I wish you all the very best for your future outside Parliament.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for once we must see that a Member of the European Parliament has made a report that tries to approach reality. It's rare enough to be pointed out. It must be said that, having exceptionally revisited its policy, we only had to follow - and this is still the best thing we do - the United States, like a dependent Europe obeying the master.  However, it seems that this appeasement is not to everyone's taste. There are several of my colleagues who are complaining and trying to damage Iran and the relations that our States must have with this great country. The going to war are here. The more they come from small powers, the more often arrogant they are. We are told about the Iranian military capabilities that we are concerned about. The armies of mercenaries that Saudi Arabia sends to Yemen do not seem to worry us, however. Double standards. We are told about Iran's harshness with regard to drug trafficking, but do we know that there are between 1.2 and 3 million drug addicts in Iran out of a population that does not reach 80 million? Do we know that Iran has lost nearly 4,000 customs officers in its war on drugs? Finally, do we remember that Iran is a sovereign state that can decide its penal system? Double standards, also if you look at Turkey.  Finally, we are told about human rights as an incantation, but are we so indignant in the face of Qatar and Saudi Arabia? Iran is an unavoidable partner. By challenging international state-to-state agreements, we risk, once again, regional and international stability. Let's support this report! It's very important because it's going in the right direction.  Iran will make its contribution to regional stability and Israel must be reassured by the full support of Parliament and our states.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, there is no doubt that the European Union's agreement with Iran on the country's nuclear programme is a major success of the European Union's foreign policy and has freed up the scope of cooperation between the two sides in various areas. Iran is the second largest economic power in the Middle East and a major player in the energy trade because it is the second country in the world in natural gas reserves and the fourth in oil. Consequently, the European Union's cooperation with Iran in various fields, such as trade, industry and energy, is in the interests of the countries of the European Union, so that they do not depend on a supplier in the energy sector.  From a political point of view this agreement is important and has been reached, because, at last, the European Union has decided to differentiate itself in foreign policy from that of the United States.
