Thus, after the nuclear agreement, it lifted sanctions against Iran, which the United States did not do, so that, in conjunction with the fact that trade with Iran takes place in dollars, there is a problem in the European Union's trade with Iran to be done in euros. Finally, Iran can be an important stabilising factor in the Middle East, but at the same time it must also improve human rights and abolish the death penalty for young people under the age of eighteen, especially children.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, the first version of the text of Richard Howitt's report looked to have been written to please Tehran and I had criticised the pro-Shiite leanings taken by the Socialist rapporteur. Similarly, many of us felt that the report was not sufficiently incisive, particularly on the issue of human rights.  The text from the Committee on Foreign Affairs that we have before us is more balanced and I would like to thank our rapporteur from the EPP Group, Elmar Brok, for his efforts to reframing the report.  I am particularly pleased to see that a number of my amendments have been taken into account, including those aimed at giving more cutting-edge to issues such as the european Union's human rights guidelines in its relations with Iran and the death penalty. The death penalty was seen in the first version of this report as a simple matter of difference between us and Iran. As we know, this is a fundamental matter of principle for the Union. The report has been improved, but I would have liked to see it as a very strong condemnation of Iran's repeated calls for the destruction of Israel, a clear condemnation of its denial of the Holocaust, a clear condemnation of Tehran's support for the regime of Bashar al-Assad and the necessary dimension of the human rights criteria that seem taboo for Richard Howitt at the moment.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the nuclear agreement with Iran is decisive, we all hope, for security and non-proliferation at regional and global level, the result of historic negotiations in which European and American diplomacy have engaged. A new page has thus opened up in European Union-Iran relations which cannot support the need for dialogue in an area where Europeans and Iranian authorities have substantial differences, with respect for human rights, including women's rights, in the use and abuse of the death penalty and other degrading treatment. This dialogue is not useless, it has to be frank, vigorous, creative: it does not fall into a bag with a government that is under pressure internally by a young society, educated and desirous of reintegration into the international community. Economic and trade opportunities are also enhanced by greater exchange between the European and Iranian peoples. The lifting of sanctions against Iran opens the Iranian market to European companies and investment. However, Iran must also commit itself and invest in complying with the recommendations of the International Financial Action Task Force to create a transparent and responsible economic environment.  But let's be clear: restricting the Euro-Iranian relationship to economic and trade objectives is to strategically fail. Iran is a regional power that should be encouraged to play a role in conflict resolution and not to aggravate them. Iran may help end the war in neighboring Syria, but today it is fighting alongside Russia to preserve the tyrant Assad at the expense of the massacred Syrian people. The European Union should use a new relationship with Iran and other regional actors to deter the Sunni-Shiite sectarian confrontation mainly fuelled by Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Erdogan's Turkey.  A solution that gives peace and future to Syrians and all peoples in the region is the only way for Europe and Iran to protect their own security.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Against the background of documents such as the Ban Ki-moon report presented to the General Assembly in September, the RESOLUTION of the US Congress and numerous think tank reports, the report that Richard Howitt presents to the European Parliament seems insufficiently balanced. As a Polish woman, I respect and value the Iranians, my comments relate to the regime of the Republic of Iran. In 1988, there were mass executions of political opponents, so massive that they were genocide. Those responsible for these murders are currently in high office, and the executions of political opponents de facto continue to this day, as do the executions of juveniles. Iran's role, both in the region and globally, is difficult to define as stabilising. The country is accused of financing terrorism. To my colleagues who are guided by the vision of trade, I wanted to remind you that the economic sector in Iran is dominated by the Revolutionary Guard, and organisations such as fatf advise with the utmost caution in making such relations.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course, I welcome the fact that the Agreement on the Iranian nuclear programme seems to be really respected. Of course, I recognise that this agreement opens up new possibilities and will bring benefits to both sides by opening up the Iranian market to European companies. Of course, I want to open our borders to young Iranians. But, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, just because the Iranian regime has ceased to be a nuclear offender does not mean that we must award it a prize for democratic and humanistic honour. In my view, openness to trade and new forms of economic cooperation, which I support, must go hand in hand with real progress in the field of human rights. I would remind you that Iran is now the world champion in all categories in terms of the number of executions in relation to the number of inhabitants. I recall that Iran executes minors, thus violating the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which it has signed and which prohibits the application of the death penalty to young offenders. I would remind you that the Iranian regime does not recognize the Holocaust. I would remind you that in Iran, all women are second-class citizens. Finally, I recall that the current Minister of Justice has publicly expressed his pride in having taken part in the decision to execute thousands of political prisoners in 1988. Personally, I call these mass executions crimes against humanity. So, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, cooperate with Iran, yes, turn a blind eye no!

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the presence of nuclear weapons makes this world an unnecessarily dangerous and volatile place. The EU’s strategies towards Iran should adhere to this basic concept. Iran stands as an example of how, ostracised by the international community, sanction states are driven away from international cooperation into a cave of isolationism.  Despite this, and unlike Israel, Iran became a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The sheer duplicity of nuclear-armed Western states criticising Iran for pursuing such objectives, while they sit on stockpiles of nuclear armaments capable of obliterating the earth several times over, would be comical if it was not so repulsive and dangerous. Of course, the most vocal opponent of Iran’s nuclear ambition was Israel; a nation with a non-declared stockpile of nuclear weapons, some of which it tried to sell to apartheid South Africa. All states in all regions should encourage and advance nuclear disarmament. The EU and Iran should ensure the terms of the agreement are fulfilled and all EU Member States should also begin unilateral nuclear disarmament and encourage non-EU nuclear-armed states to do likewise.  Sinn Féin, for our part, will ensure that we promote universal nuclear disarmament as a means to remove these immoral, military, useless and potentially Armageddon—creating weapons. To this end we will work to uphold Ireland’s neutrality and to oppose the British Government’s drive to renew its trident weapons of mass destruction. I also want to acknowledge the work of Richard Howitt and to wish him well in the future.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Iran nuclear agreement is certainly a great diplomatic success which brings back to the negotiating table a regional player fundamental to the balance of the entire Middle East, such as Iran, perhaps one of the few successes of recent years. And ours will be a vote in favour, a vote of encouragement for the progress that the current Haroni-led executive is making in the country. A vote that, however, does not forget the serious human rights situation, which does not forget the use of the death penalty even on minors, although, remember, it is certainly not the country with the highest number in the world, that is China, but it seems that many people forget it when it comes to the example of the ES MES China; it does not forget censorship either and does not forget holocaust denial. However, we need a positive attitude, an attitude that led to the conclusion of the Treaty itself, an attitude that we must preserve so that the moderate wing prevails in its battle against the conservative wing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposed report presents some rather interesting points of view but does not, in some respects, go beyond its logic. It is not a question of giving a white-seing to the Islamic Republic of Iran, far from it. However, once special attention is paid to the essential point of the fight against the Islamic State, it is clear that Iran is becoming an essential partner in the fight against terrorism, which unfortunately is not the case for a number of European States which have, precisely, remained silent in relation to this fight against the Islamic State.  I also warn here against the hypocritical initiatives of the United States which, when it comes to certain European companies, want to maintain an embargo. As long as Iran fully and truly implements the Geneva agreements, sanctions must be proportionately and proportionately lifted against that state.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: "Don't you see that you're funny?" The European Union, which has seven years behind it and thirty billion debts, internal and external problems, instructs a country that has four thousand years of tradition about what to do? You instruct Iran to abolish the death penalty and respect the constitution, and yet iran's constitution dictates the use of the death penalty. You say they have to get rid of the atom, but we know countries like Pakistan, Israel, America that have nuclear weapons and are quite civilized. You say that Iran is going to abolish the death penalty, but we know countries like the US, Japan – very civilised – that have the death penalty because you have a colonial mentality. Just as you were instructing Africans a hundred years ago on how to live, just as you now instruct the proud Persians on how to live. They don't have to listen to that.  What would you say if Iran did a conference, read these European Union documents and said that the Union must restore the death penalty in order to become a civilised state again? And who told you that EU values are better than Iranian values? Who told you? You are imperialists who do not tolerate differences, and besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The nuclear agreement with Iran was good news among many very bad news from the region and from around the European Union. The good news was not just the "deal" itself, but the implementation process, which was a process of building trust between partners. The merit of the External Action Service is undisputed. All the knowledge I have accumulated as head of the Delegation for Iran in the European Parliament tells me that there is no better way to support the forces that we call reformers than to open Iran up to the world and cooperate in as wide a field as possible. There is no better option. This is also attested to by the new composition of the 'match list', that is to say, the European Parliament, which was formed after the agreement was concluded. Now it is important that the average person, "man in the street", in Tehran will feel the effects of this opening in his living standards.  Of course, it is not easy to find a point of balance between geopolitical, economic and defence interests of values that we will never give up. Mr Howitt's report is a search for this balance. It points to the fields of cooperation – that is, the economy with the name of the bottleneck, which is banking services, environmental protection, energy, the fight against drug smuggling – but it also speaks of differences and calls them by name: the number of death sentences, the treatment of ethnic and religious minorities, Iran's unsatisfactory role as a stabiliser of the region. I firmly believe that in relations with Iran, the opportunities outweigh the threats.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the rapporteur, Mr Howitt, I am speaking in favour of a report that is heading in the right direction: it is a balanced proposal that must be read and considered in all its points, paragraphs, including commas. A position of the European Parliament that supports the valuable work of the High Representative Federica Mogherini who defined the nuclear agreement, of which this report is somehow the daughter, a sign of hope for the world at a time when hope seems to be in crisis. That agreement is based on respect for the rules that must be closely monitored. But that is not enough, we must now create a climate of mutual trust between Iran and the European Union. Relations must be developed through a dialogue at several levels involving political, diplomatic, economic, academic, technical and interpersonal contacts, including civil society actors, NGOs and human rights defenders. A dialogue, it was said, wide-ranging, open, frank, critical, when necessary. We have common economic interests, I am thinking in particular of the fight against climate change. Iran ranks second in the world for gas reserves, fourth for oil. Energy cooperation can play a significant role in diversifying sources of supply for the European Union. The Eu ropean Union can support Iran in its various environmental challenges, including water scarcity and the fight against desertification.  We invest confidently in young Europeans and Iranians to bring societies and cultures closer together, increasing exchanges between students and researchers. Finally, I would like to read out the European Parliament's call in the report: 'calls on Iran to respect, protect and comply with its commitments under the Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran, the International Covenant on Political and Civil Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, respecting freedom of expression, opinion, association, thought and freedom of expression. , of conscience, religion without ethnic or social discrimination or sexual orientation". On this basis – I finished, Mr President – it is possible to work together to ensure peace, stability in the Middle East, combat terrorism and prevent the tragedy of millions of refugees.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I'll tell you right away. I do not intend to give my approval to a report if it can be used in the hands of a theocratic regime in Iran and become a propaganda tool.  We have been negotiating the nuclear agreement for years and in the meantime we have seen a dramatic increase in the number of executions in Iran. According to the United Nations, some 1 000 people were hanged last year alone. That's the highest number of executions per capita in the world.  Iran is also the record holder in the number of executions of minors. Yes, under pressure from the European Union's tough sanctions, Iran was forced to scale back its nuclear ambitions and accept the nuclear agreement, which is necessary. But let's not be naïve. This does not mean that we are now suddenly faced with a more moderate regime. The daily reality proves otherwise.  An example? The same officials who executed 30 000 political prisoners in 1988, and thus committed one of the most serious crimes against humanity, still occupy top positions in the current regime. One is the current Minister of Justice. He even recently stated that he is proud of the role he played in the massacre!  We also see Iran's destructive role in the region's conflicts. Iran provides the financial resources, the weapons and the militiamen for its proxy wars in Syria, in Iraq, in Yemen, in Lebanon and elsewhere. If Iran is to finally be a responsible state with which we too can do business, it must first of all stop that kind of rogue behaviour.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, about a year ago a historic agreement was reached with Iran which represented a milestone in the fight against nuclear proliferation and an important step towards making the world a safer place.  With the lifting of economic and financial sanctions related to Iran's nuclear programme, Europe has sought to seize the opportunities that a market of 80 million people represents, even if it has to turn a blind eye to the constant human rights violations of the dictatorial regime of the Ayatolas.  But if it is true that Europe does everything to benefit from these opportunities, it is no less true that the expansion of institutional and trade relations must be strictly conditional on iran's progress in the field of human rights.  I therefore believe that the motion for a resolution on Iran which was voted this month by the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the European Parliament does not reflect this conditionality and maintains an unacceptable business stance as usual in the face of an oppressive regime that systematically manipulates the democratic process, holds a sad record of human rights violations, is the world leader in per capita executions and under-18s , and is a repressive of women and religious minorities.  For all this, Mr Howitt, I believe that it is our duty to make this resolution not a mere instrument of political propaganda for the theocratic regime in Tehran, which, as a regime that needs this level of violence to repress its own citizens, shows great weaknesses in order to become a genuine credible and reliable diplomatic and economic partner for the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, human rights are not negotiable, they are part of our collective responsibility as human beings and Europeans!

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, some 30 years ago, 30 000 political prisoners, including thousands of women, were executed in Iran. Some of those executed were only 15 years old, some were pregnant. Those responsible for these crimes are still involved in leading actions, and they even boast proud of what they are doing. Such persons must be brought before the International Court of Justice immediately, and this cannot simply be watched from the sidelines, even though time has passed.  It must be understood that this is not just about nuclear weapons. As we increase cooperation, we must consistently demand respect for human rights. Cooperation will only benefit everyone if it is done from the right starting points. We must not abandon the Iranian people in order to enter the country's huge market. Not even if some other countries act differently. Money must not take precedence over democracy and human rights.  We must remember that the power of religious ultra-conservatives is cemented in the Iranian system and democratic reforms cannot be pushed through without its approval. Iran is not the only undemocratic and human rights-trampling country in the Middle East. The EU must be balanced. Stability can only be built through the most coherent action. The West must finally put human rights and peace-building above all power games.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Once the nuclear agreement has been concluded, the EU now needs a new strategy towards Iran, because the agreement offers an opportunity for reforms at the political, economic and civil level. The European External Action Service is already taking this into account with the establishment of an Iran Task Force and the opening of an EU delegation in Tehran. However, trade and economic relations are now of particular importance. This opens up great potential for European companies. In the first half of this year alone, in the context of the agreement, the volume of trade between Iran and Europe increased by 43%, and 30 Iranian banks joined the SWIFT. The Iranian government is very ambitious and aims to achieve annual economic growth of 8 percent. To do this, the country needs foreign direct investment. Over the next ten years alone, EUR 1 000 billion will be invested in the development of infrastructure. Iran is also the second largest economy in the Middle East, and the current volume of trade between the EU and Iran is expected to quadruple over the next two years. The EU was Iran's largest trading partner before the sanctions, and it must now be our aim for the EU to regain this top position.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The nuclear deal with Iran was reached in July 2015. Unfortunately, however, the lifting of sanctions has been slow and only partial. In particular, the United States has hampered bank lending cooperation. I quote from the report: "A realistic assessment of common interests and differences is needed." Yes, the difference must also be realistically measured, that it is a country with a different culture, a different value system. Most of the criticism is from Iran for executions for drug crimes. However, consider the country's vulnerability: 86% of opium seizures take place in Iran. An amendment proposes that economic cooperation should be conditional on the abolition of the death penalty. If this Parliament votes for this, then be consistent and immediately terminate the TTIP negotiations with the United States, because most states in the United States still have the death penalty.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Vienna agreement on Iran's nuclear programme has opened a new stage in Iran's relations with the European Union and with the international community at large. The full implementation of the agreement must remain a priority for us, although its progressive implementation makes it possible to move towards a broader and more constructive bilateral relationship.  The verifications carried out by the International Atomic Energy Agency allow us, today, to work on new areas of cooperation and to take advantage of the opportunities presented, from political dialogue to trade and investment, to energy and the environment. A dialogue in which we must not forget our principles, so human rights must also be present, as you yourself confirmed a few minutes ago, Commissioner.  On the other hand, Iran's importance in the regional framework is clear: its contest is central to the solution of the various crises currently in the Middle East. In particular, I am referring to the conflict in Syria and the fight against the Dáesh.  Iran must have a more constructive attitude in the pursuit of peace in Syria and also in the fight against terrorism; it must use its ancestry over some of the groups and countries operating in the region to avoid an even greater escalation of regional conflicts.  We need Iran to contribute to the security of the region and to that of its member countries, including Israel. There are no exceptions.  Iran, based on the implementation of the Vienna agreement, must continue to gain the sympathy of the international community and actively contribute to peace, overcoming religious clashes and struggles for regional hegemony that are tearing apart the Middle East and the Muslim community.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Madam President, this is not really a point of order. I have just had an intervention, that of my colleague M millin Mon, without any translation into French. I do not know if this is a problem with Spanish or the French cabin, but I would like to understand and hear the rest of our debate.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, Commissioner, I would like to thank rapporteur Mr Richard Howitt for a very balanced report. This report stresses all the positive changes that have happened in Iran recently, outlining future cooperation between the EU and Iran. But from the other side it contains criticisms and highlights the challenges that we face. In spite of some unsolved problems, I would like to say that it is a success story for our diplomacy. In the last year Iranian and European diplomacy managed to raise our relations from a very low point and to give our relations a positive trend. Iran is our partner in the fight against ISIS and al-Nusra, which are designated terrorist organisations by the United Nations Security Council. The European Parliament should play an important role in the process of establishing a friendly cooperation framework with Iran in which we can receive positive results in the issues we are interested in or resolve problems we are concerned about. In this way we should be wise and patient and try to avoid the temptation to use offensive language. Why? Because emotional criticism will lead us to the opposite direction. It helps Iranian conservatives, who are very strong and who resist any improving relations with the Western world. I do not think that this is what we really want. That is why I would like to invite you to support Richard Howitt’s balanced and wise approach.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – This report purports to provide an EU strategy for Iran. However, how is this possible when the leading political forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran are completely disregarded? Think of Supreme Leader Khamenei and the Iranian Revolutionary Guard. Mr Howitt, an incomprehensible omission! This report is one major case for business as usual with Iran. However, the biggest profiteer of this policy will not be the population but the Iranian Revolutionary Guard, by virtue of its dominant and exalted position in the country's economy. The destabilising, revolutionary role of this power-sharing chief Khamenei, in the region and beyond, is evident. Again, an incomprehensible omission! This report conceals the Iranian urge for destruction towards the Jewish state of Israel. It also conceals Iranian denial and even ridicule of the Holocaust. My amendments, Mr Rapporteur, muffled you away, you rejected them: a minus one! For the third time: an incomprehensible, immoral omission. Ladies and gentlemen, therefore, support Mrs Schaake's corrective amendment, which I myself signed. Madam President, this report does not provide an EU strategy for Iran. It's political fiction. On the contrary, it encourages the EU and its Member States to continue the cunning, disastrous erroneous path towards Tehran. The damage and shame for the European Union and for the supporters of this report will, I fear, not be minor!

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the agreement with Iran is a very important milestone, we agree. But this diplomatic success, ladies and gentlemen, let us not forget, has been done dealing with a state, with a regime of terror. A fundamentalist regime, which continues to execute systematically, that denies the Holocaust, that executes children and also perpetrated torture on a daily basis.  I believe in Iran's future because I believe in the Iranians. I know very well your love for freedom and your millennial courage and that is why I know that one day you will be rid of the tyranny of the clerics.  I support High Representative Mogherini's initiative and applaud her excellent diplomatic work.  But I am absolutely against any form of appeasement like the one that intends to spread the far left, like my colleagues at Podemos. How much money has your mullah leader received? How much funding for "television production" does it receive each week from a state that finances terrorism? Why doesn't your leader denounce executions and torture in Iran? Why does its leader not publicly condemn and denounce the systematic violation of women's rights or the appalling persecution and execution of homosexuals?  Some are willing to accept the money of Iranian tyranny for their own purposes. More than that, there are those who have accepted it to finance their propaganda, but the Europeanists, we cannot sell our principles. No, ladies and gentlemen, we can't.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the nuclear agreement signed between Iran and the members of the United Nations Security Council in 2015 is very good news. It was good news for international relations. It is only necessary to compare how weapons of mass destruction were treated in Iraq—without diplomacy, without heeding the rapporteurs or united Nations investigators—and what happened when diplomacy has been launched.  It is good news also for the stability of the region and is good news for nuclear non-proliferation — something that should also apply to Israel, which has more than three hundred nuclear warheads, which also violates human rights, and no one tells it anything.  But in this European Union strategy report with Iran we fall back into the mistakes that strengthen international relations: we do not call for the full lifting of US sanctions — unilateral, extraterritorial sanctions, which also affect Union companies, but which affect, above all, the Iranian people.  Putting Hezbola at al Nusra level is crazy or a myopia. Why? Because Hezbola is a political-military organization that is part of the Lebanese government, it has several ministers. And besides, we haven't included the political side in those terrorist organizations. And Al Nusra is Al Qaeda. Let's not forget, please.  When we ask for respect for human rights—refugees, asylum requests—we can agree, but we may first have to apply it to ourselves before we give lessons.  In short, Mr Howitt, this is not a bad report, but in my view it is one step away from what should be the basis for a good understanding among sovereign nations.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I consider this resolution to be an imposition on Iran.  Mr Howitt was right to point out that there was once a principle of non-interference in the affairs of other peoples. I think that in 34 places we are holding Iran in front of something that we would not otherwise have for the other countries. How far have we come with the United States? Several members have mentioned it: it is not just the death penalty that applies in Israel – israel, incidentally, the death penalty – but also the killing of people, of foreigners abroad, without trial, without fair trials, without the rule of law, and nobody says that we cannot negotiate with these states. What about Saudi Arabia? What is it like: we buy cars from South Korea and Japan, even though there is the death penalty there.  Paragraph 34 calls for full respect for the sovereignty of all states in the region. Let us start with the EU! Our aircraft are violating full sovereignty in this region every day.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, like most of us I also welcome the nuclear agreement signed with Iran. After the agreement we need to find a way to reengage Iran with the international community. First of all we need to work on political engagement in Iran. Here we can contribute with inter-parliamentary dialogue between the European Parliament and the Majlis. Before strengthening economic and trade ties, however – and I want to emphasise this – we have to make sure that Iran is fully respecting international standards, especially those concerning human rights. This includes changing the policy of the Iranian regime towards the death penalty, especially in cases of the execution of juveniles. It needs to be clear that the EU stands on the side of respect for human rights and human life. This has been central to EU human rights and foreign policy, and it has to stay like that in our future relations with Iran. Although I believe that opening relations with Iran can be beneficial for the Middle East region and the EU, we have to remain vigilant in areas of security and the fight against terrorism. Relations with Iran are still very fragile. The EU can be an important partner for Iran; however, we will need to find mutual understanding beyond the use of nuclear energy.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as has been mentioned by many colleagues, the agreement signed in July 2015 represents a unique opportunity to try to place Iran in an international context. We cannot miss this opportunity, because without Iran there would be no real possibility of creating a security structure in that part of the world. It won't be easy. The issues to be addressed are those that have been mentioned, some of which have already been successfully resolved at least in the first impact, and others, on the other hand, will have to be retraced in order to arrive at definitive solutions.  I personally believe that, as far as the issue of human rights is concerned, this is objectively the priority of our future work. With regard to the death penalty, the situation of minors and women, freedom of expression and religion, they are the key to a future structure that is not only acceptable, but which has the traits and characteristics of a civilisation that helps to guarantee security not only at home, but for the whole world. So we will have to work on this. However, we must welcome the progress that has been made on these sensitive issues too. The report therefore has a positive trait which must be recognised and will have to be approved with conviction. Finally, I would like to add that we must then focus in the future on the relationship between the parliaments of the European States and the Iranian Parliament: it is not enough just the report that has already been created, we must also consolidate other hypothetical relations that will be useful for our future.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I have heard our rapporteur, Mr Howitt, and I thank him for this work, the complexity and scale of which are well understood here. But we have the impression, all the same, that we have acted as if relations between the European Union and Iran are already perfectly normalised after the Vienna agreement. The 51 paragraphs in the report are in keeping with an optimism that often seems excessive and sometimes even angelic. Certainly, the country is opening up. It reopens, I will say, to exchanges, to cooperation, to tourism itself, but I do not forget its right side. The Islamic Republic, whatever its President Rohani says, remains - and these are the facts reported by all the NGOs on the ground - a totalitarian theocracy that knows no human rights.  Paragraph 41, in this regard, is explicit: Iran holds a sad record, that of the highest number of executions per capita in the world. It is also, as has been said here, the last country to put to death juvenile offenders, which is a flagrant violation of international law and our fundamental values in Europe, as well as the denial of justice, the fate reserved for women, the institutionalized denial of the Holocaust, the call for the destruction of Israel - not a word here - and the leadership in Beirut of Hezbollah , a terrorist organization that plays a leading role in Syria alongside the Damascus regime.  These are all reasons why I will not be able to vote on this report tomorrow if the series of amendments I have tabled with my group and a series of others, which I have heard today, are not accepted.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank you, Commissioner Cañete, for your balanced and critical approach to this topic. First of all, we need to face some basic facts. For example, just now, Narges Mohammadi, a family mother and leader of Iran’s human rights centre, was sentenced additionally for sixteen years’ imprisonment for her human rights activities. Iran continues to rank first in the world considering executions per capita. The Iranian regime has been and continues to be one of the main sources of export of terrorism in the region and has contributed heavily in the emergence of Daesh. These are some facts why the current EU approach can be seen as premature and unbalanced, where EU values and fundamental rights of Iranians are sidelined. The main EU asset is our economic potential, which mullahs desperately need to keep riding on the tiger. But the only way to have a positive impact is firm conditionality between economic relations and credible progress in respect of basic human rights. This is a key moment – conditionality – which this report lacks, with all due respect to our colleague Howitt for his serious work. Iran continues to be one of the most brutal regimes in the world. And one fact: the current Minister of Justice has turned out to be responsible for the mass murders of 34 000 political prisoners in 1988. He claims he is proud of it. We cannot make deals with a person who has bloody hands. Therefore I agree with colleague Schaake that if the ALDE amendments will not be adopted tomorrow, then it will be very difficult to vote for this report.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will jointly approve the report on the EU's strategy towards Iran after the nuclear agreement. In paragraph 12, we are talking about the Iranian people. We call on the EU to develop economic cooperation with their country in order to improve the living conditions of Iranian citizens. I would like to appeal to the Iranian people to think first in other respects. On the Iranian side, re-establishing relations must represent an opportunity and a boon not only to government business and business, but also, above all, to political prisoners. For ordinary people whose relatives have been unjustly executed in recent years. For those closest to them who are unjustly condemned to such punishment now. I am afraid that if our partner is a country with the highest number of executions per capita in the world, it pays to be very careful.  Now, ladies and gentlemen, let me speak English. I want to commemorate 30,000 political prisoners in Iran who were murdered between August and October 1988. This is a crime against humanity that has remained unpunished. Those who committed those crimes are still at the top of the regime. Therefore, colleagues, please support the amendments to this report.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it was with great concern that I read the rapporteur’s original report. Not even once in the text was Iran condemned for its human rights abuses. Not even once was the support for terrorists mentioned. The Iranian policy of anti-Semitism and of calling for the destruction of Israel was completely left out. In the lead-up to the vote in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Iranian embassies sent me and other Members of this Parliament a letter, a letter in which the agents of the regime expressed their great satisfaction with Mr Howitt’s report. In fact the ambassadors representing one of the world’s most brutal dictatorships expect us as Members of  Parliament to support this text. At the same time, Iranian state media have reported that the EU will now, through this report, give its support to the regime and its actions.  The compromise amendments make the report slightly better, and I would like to thank the EPP shadow rapporteur, Mr Brok, for his efforts, but this Parliament has a long tradition of placing human rights at the very core of its relations with other countries. For that reason, I have decided to vote tomorrow for the amendments tabled by the ALDE Group, which will make the report somewhat more balanced.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also welcome the nuclear agreement with Iran and agree that the economic relationship with Iran is very important and That European investment is crucial to enhance its economic potential. It is known that economic cooperation is the fastest way to generate positive change in a society and is indeed an open door to improving the human rights situation and respect for international law, especially as we are referring to Iran, a state ruled by a totalitarian regime. Clear economic measures are absolutely necessary, in a transparent, anti-corruption economy and the guarantee of civil rights and freedoms.  At the same time, an approach to the relationship with Iran exclusively from an economic point of view, as this report now reflects, is counterproductive in the long run and unrealistic. The report ignores abuses and overlooks flagrant human rights violations. This approach I think brings services to Iranian citizens, but also to the long-term relationship between us and Iran. As an MEP and a European, I do not want the double standard to become a constant of our policy both inside and outside the Union. The totalitarian regime in Iran refuses to acknowledge its mistakes and implement real reforms, which raises a lot of questions about the future of the relationship between Iran and the European Union. Tehran's aggressive speech, especially in relation to Israel, and support to terrorist organizations do not provide international partners with the necessary guarantee on a sensitive issue as nuclear. Thank.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I fear that, without the amendments by our colleagues Mr Deprez and Mrs Schaake, the resolution on relations between the EU and the Islamic Republic of Iran would resemble a document by some European—Iranian chamber of commerce.  In this Parliament we regularly adopt urgent resolutions on unjustly imprisoned activists and victims of state violence. We award the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. We would expect that, if we decided to take a stand concerning the Islamic Republic of Iran, we would harshly condemn the executions of thousands of women and young people, we would draw more attention to how the Iranian regime is persecuting people for their beliefs and, in particular, we would demand an investigation into the 1988 massacre in which the regime executed more than 30 000 political prisoners. I understand that in politics it is sometimes necessary to show goodwill despite reservations, but even then we must not cross the red line that separates politics and diplomacy from faceless cynicism. That line is called human dignity. A state that does not respect human dignity can hardly become a trusted partner.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in this difficult dossier, I would just like to leave three ideas. A first, to congratulate me on the signing of this agreement. This action plan may represent a very important milestone on the road to the political stabilization of a region that has been marked by instability and also by the existence of numerous conflicts that insist on maintaining and causing a high level of suffering to various peoples of this broad territory. Secondly, I would like to remind all those who reject gradual approaches, in which change and solidarity are being built step by step and to the extent of concrete achievements and the establishment of bonds of trust, understanding and mutual acceptance, that our European Union was designed exactly in this way by the founding fathers, stating this very well Robert Schuman in his well-known statement. And that is why i believe that change operates more easily, more quickly and more solidly through approximation and not through blind conditionality, pure imposition, absolute denial of paternalism and cultural prejudices, which I generally agree with the position adopted by the AFET Commission. Before I finish, I would like to stress that there are universal principles on which we cannot compromise and the death penalty is one of them. I have made several amendments to this effect and that is why I insist in plenary, although it is already written in the resolution, asking once again to iranian officials to, as a demonstration of their commitment to this rapprochement between our peoples, immediately impose a moratorium on the execution of death sentences in their country.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are discussing a report today which deals with a very difficult issue. On the one hand, of course, it is the result of an agreement with Iran signed a year ago in Vienna, with the result that we are eliminating, I hope, one of the countries that can possess nuclear weapons and threaten others.  On the other hand, this agreement – and a lot of time has been devoted to it – offers an opportunity to increase economic cooperation between the European Union and Iran. This is extremely important for both sides, including the Iranian people and the peoples of our Member States. Both need to diversify energy sources: gas, oil. This agreement offers great opportunities for mutual investment, which may go not in the hundreds of billions of euros, but even in trillions. On the other hand, there are values that are more important than economic development and even than new jobs, and peace is undoubtedly the highest value. However, Iran is not a country that has so far created security, on the contrary, it has been a country that has threatened security in the region and in the world.  I therefore believe that it is necessary to pursue this agreement and to increase economic exchanges, trade, investment, but also to examine the state of implementation on the Iranian side. This country lives on a bakier with values that are important to our civilization, and therefore will not guarantee peace in the region and in the world until economic issues can prevail over our cooperation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the expansion of economic relations with Iran cannot come at the cost of ignoring other things that are of core value to the European Union. The improvement of the human rights situation is a must. Iran must improve the state of women’s rights, freedom of expression and abolish the death penalty. Iran has joined the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, under which it has the obligation to stop the execution of juvenile offenders. So this is what it must do: stop executing children. Iran also has to release all political prisoners and others that are unjustly detained. The harassment of journalists and the prosecution of Iranian dual nationals has to stop. It is important to guarantee access to fair trial, access to a lawyer and that there will be an end to the systematic torture in prisons. The abolition of the death penalty is a key objective of EU human rights and foreign policy, and we cannot forget that in our relations with Iran. Iran has an important influence in the region, so it can – and should – play a stabilising role in the region. We call on Iran to play a constructive role in solving the political crisis in Syria and in Iraq, and so on, and cooperate with the EU in countering terrorism and violent extremism in the region.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a member of the Iranian delegation, I have had ample opportunities to have delegations coming, under our chairman Lewandowski, to discuss many of the issues raised here this evening. I think, on balance, we are getting the right approach. We have to say that the nuclear agreement – and the European Commission played a very important part in it – was one of the great achievements in recent times. That probably, and COP21, were the two greatest national agreements in recent times. Iran has come a long way, because they stepped back from the nuclear armament because they trusted those of us who were involved in negotiating. Now we have to deliver in terms of economic cooperation but also, as has been pointed out very strongly, a very firm hand must be held with them with regard to human rights and especially the death penalty, which is over-used, without any doubt (if it can ever be justified), in their state. So I think we are on the right track, but economic cooperation and human rights together is the best way forward.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the historic nuclear agreement signed last year in Vienna was an important milestone for international diplomacy and for the process of détente in relations between Iran and the West. This is a remarkable achievement for multilateral diplomacy and for European diplomacy in particular, which was also achieved thanks, and perhaps above all, to the work and tenacity of the High Representative for Foreign Policy Federica Mogherini. This result must allow not only a significant improvement in EU-Iran relations, but also the promotion of stability throughout the region. If respected, this agreement can be a good guide on which to build a new season of peace relations between the European Union and Iran, which was once an important trading partner, but for this to happen it is essential that Iran promotes the new season of respect for rights and freedoms, starting precisely from a moratorium on executions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Iran can be an important partner for the Member States of the Union, as it is an economy with great potential, but also a potential pole of stability in the wider region, provided that it fully respects human rights. After all, Europe was Iran's first trading partner before the sanctions were implemented. The lifting of sanctions therefore offers important opportunities. The European External Action Service must work productively, with a view to fully restoring relations, impartially and solely in the interests of citizens. It must emphasise the priorities for public and small and medium-sized enterprises, not only in the energy sector but also in other sectors. In particular, the possibilities for cooperation in the construction sector need to be considered, because Iran is a country with rapid growth, while, on the other hand, in countries such as Greece, it is the construction industry that has been hardest hit by the economic crisis and austerity policies. The European Union must therefore encourage extroversion, not just in words and not only where it is in the interests of German multinationals.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, tomorrow, 25 October, will be the second anniversary of the death of Reyhaneh Jabbari, executed for defending herself against sexual assault by an agent of the Iranian regime when she was 19 years old. We mourn her still, and so in her name I urge the EU External Action Service to set out a clear human rights framework as part of the EU’s engagement with the Iranian Government going forward from this report. There must be a human rights impact assessment, benchmarks and a framework for monitoring and evaluation. This must cover ongoing human rights violations such as the use of torture, the imprisonment of political activists and human rights defenders, and the need to prohibit the execution of children and work towards the elimination of the death penalty. Real progress must be made on women’s rights and the criminalisation of gender-based violence, such as acid attacks on women. The External Action Service must engage constructively with the Iranian authorities on human rights, put them at the core of the process and strive to achieve meaningful progress for people on the ground. Finally, I would like to call on the Iranian Government to free the Anglo-Iranian mother Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who has been imprisoned and detained since April this year.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for speaking so clearly. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in ensuring that the joint comprehensive plan of action works for all sides and ultimately that balanced bilateral relations can lead to Iran’s reintegration into the international community, politically, economically and socially, as well as to building a more constructive real environment.  Let me reiterate that we are set to pursue this agenda of balance and incremental engagement, contingent upon the implementation of the joint comprehensive plan of action. But we know that implementation is an ongoing task and we need to be diligent and vigilant in our joint efforts throughout the lifetime of the agreement. Many Members have referred to the important issue of human rights. Major differences on some issues persist, but we have an opportunity to engage with an influential political player, not least on issues on which we disagree. Human rights remain a matter of concern for the European Union,  especially the high number of executions, including those of juvenile offenders and political prisoners.  I would like to close by expressing, once again, my appreciation of Parliament’s role in bringing this important issue to the agenda. I would like, finally, also to repeat my thanks to Mr Howitt for all the work that he has done on this report.  We wish him every success in the future.

name: Richard Howitt
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Brok, Mr Tannock, Mr Carver, Ms Anderson, Mr Castaldo, Mr Lewandowski, Mr Mamikins, Mr Cofferati, Mr Kelly and Mr Caputo for their very kind words. I appreciate it. Thank you to Mr Buchner and others who have mentioned the issue of dual nationals. I have myself met the relatives of Mr Foroughi and Ms Zaghari-Ratcliffe and we do call for their – and others’ – release in paragraph 47. I have not engaged with the far right in 22 years and I will not start debating with them now, but I do take the questions from PPE and ALDE colleagues seriously. To my friends in the ALDE Group and with greatest respect to Ms Schaake, you say you support the nuclear agreement and the High Representative, yet you submit amendments that you know will undermine it. You have even rejected the compromise that I have offered you on the Holocaust, and you should think again about that.  You say that my report is lacking on human rights and on ending support for Hezbollah. There are 34 references to human rights. In reality, is there any number which would be high enough for you? Ending support for Hezbollah is there in paragraph 34. You cite free and fair elections, the justice system and the treatment of women, yet it is all there: paragraphs 39, 46 and 49. The truth is that I believe you are against the agreement and, if your Group votes against the report, I have to say that I believe it is you who are being illiberal, not me. To Mr Preda, my report is strictly balanced in seeking to reject sectarianism and to support reconciliation between Tehran and Riyadh. For you to suggest that my Group is itself sectarian is beneath you. As fellow direct colleagues in this Parliament’s Subcommittee on Human Rights, you know that I support human rights benchmarks, but choose to say otherwise. Look at my support for a return to a human rights dialogue and also for assessing investment according to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. When Mr Adaktusson says that my original draft did not have human rights at all – it is just wholly false. I have asked you to examine your consciences and you should do so before saying that. To Mr Belder, sovereignty for Israel as well as other countries in the Middle East is there – in paragraphs 34 and 35 – and you should remember that I personally was author of the written declaration on responsibility for the Holocaust. To many Members, I am interested in how often the words ‘propaganda for a theocratic regime’ have been repeated across this debate. It does point to the lobbying interest behind many of the criticisms aired. To my friend, Ms Ries, the step-by-step process I describe in paragraph 4 is hardly what you called normalisation.  Mr Kelam paid me a compliment, for which I thank him, but he and others who referred to ISIS-Daesh must recognise that they are just as much an enemy of Iran as to us. To Mr Ruas and all who referred to the death penalty, I reiterate that my report clearly states that Iran has the highest per capita execution rate, that we oppose the death penalty and call for an immediate moratorium. I understand that you want to be associated with these calls, but this report hardly needs amendment to achieve them.  Finally, I remember sitting in an Embassy of a Member State in the Middle East, being told that the bombing of Iran was more likely than not. Another Middle East war with all the consequences. European diplomacy has helped avert that terrible fate and we should be very careful in this Parliament about acting irresponsibly in a way that could jeopardise it.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 25 October, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Sanctions were serious political hypocrisy and a double standard. The EU continues to trade with Saudi Arabia and Turkey, where drastic human rights violations are bloody daily. Signing the agreement with Iran is a huge step forward in normalizing our relations with this country. Iran is a country with huge economic potential and deep traditions, the only stable country in an explosive region. Iran can be an important partner of the EU. This normalisation of relations must be based on mutual respect and respect for the internal order and the right of each sovereign state to build its society on the basis of its traditions. Any so-called "no-fly zone" will be A "comprehensive agreement" with Iran that will require the country to change its device and traditions or abandon its interests in the region and on the international stage is completely unacceptable, disrespectful and doomed to fail. Such failure is not in the EU's interest, but only for dangerous and dictatorial regimes in Turkey and Saudi Arabia. That is why I will vote against this resolution.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – The latest events show that the relationship between the EU and Iran has reached a detente. Iran is the second-largest economy in the Middle East with an estimated nominal GDP of 397 billion USD in 2015. EU trade with Iran currently stands at USD 8 billion and is expected to quadruple in the next two years. Half of Iranian households’ energy needs are met by natural gas. Iran has on average 300 days of sunshine per year; we need to take into consideration the potential of developing renewable energies in Iran. Iran’s ratification of the rights of the child prohibits child executions and Iran must ensure that that child execution, arbitrary and political executions stop. I also believe that joining the extractive transparency initiative is an effective measure. EU relationships with Iran must come with shared values on people’s rights, with freedom for those politically detained, with real justice for the dead and with stopping the dictatorship. Any dictatorship based on fear and injustice is meant to fail. My call to the Iranian leadership is to stop the abuses and the imprisonment of the political opponents and to build a society based on freedom. Only free people can take a country forward.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Laura Ferrara, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the fight against corruption and the follow-up to the RESOLUTION of the CRIM Committee (2015/2110(INI)) (A8-0284/2016).

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is taking a significant step forward today. In order to combat the spread of corruption and organised crime effectively, a debate had to be established at European level aimed at introducing common laws and law enforcement measures in all Member States. This Europe has, in fact, been seriously to blame: it has relegated the fight against corruption and organised crime, including mafia-style crime, to strictly national borders. The lack of awareness of the transnational scope of this phenomenon has thus guaranteed easy play for the Mafia and, more generally, for criminal organisations which, also using corruption, have identified new businesses by infiltrating the management of migrant reception centres or by hoarding tenders financed from European funds or investing in the main financial centres, thus benefiting from the lack of recognition of the danger of the phenomenon of associations in some Member States.  All this requires urgent and incisive regulatory action at European level to stop the spread of criminal organisations on the continent, to combat the crimes most commonly committed by mafias and to prevent associations from infiltrating the legal economy. The European Parliament is playing its part with great commitment and conviction, amid a thousand difficulties that arise above all from cultural and legal differences, from existing prejudices against the different forms of criminal organisations rooted in the Member States. During the last parliamentary term, the path we are completing today was opened up, not only to introduce a common concept of a crime of association with mafia-type crimes, but above all to adopt a shared and effective strategy to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering.  The hope is that the other European institutions will also fully understand the real danger of these now transnational phenomena, that they will not only focus on fine crime but that they will become aware of the danger that comes from membership of the association. These phenomena do not only affect the legal economy, but affect the entire civil coexistence on which the European Union is founded.  Ladies and gentlemen, allow me first of all to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation and for the interesting and productive discussions that have taken place throughout the meetings. Allow me also to thank the European Parliament's Research Centre for its study of the costs of the European Union's failure to act in the fight against corruption and organised crime, which has been instrumental in finding us some ideas and objective bases for the drafting of this report. Thanks go to Eurojust, which replied to the questionnaire we sent by providing us with important information on how to improve cooperation and the exchange of information between Member States. Another thanks goes to Europol for the many comparisons that have taken place and for the valuable information it has provided, in particular on the more practical aspects of coordination between the different procedures of the individual countries and on how to overcome the difficulties encountered. Thanks go to the European Commission, which has always been available for discussions and debates on the fight against corruption and organised crime.  Thanks go to those citizens who contributed to the drafting of the report on the Internet and in particular on the Rousseau portal of the 5 Star Movement, thus taking an interest in the first person and providing us with important suggestions. I would also like to thank all my fellow Members who have tabled many amendments to the report, which also proves that the subject is extremely much felt at transnational level and is not a national phenomenon. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the opinions of the DEVE and CONT committees and thank, if I may thank them, all the staff, young and old, and all the staff who, believing in the work they have carried out, have contributed passionately to the work of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, organised crime is undoubtedly a global threat and as such requires a joint and well-balanced response from the European Union and the Member States. Due to the evolution of the modus operandi of criminal organisations, full awareness of the complexity of this phenomenon and of the danger arising from infiltration into the economic, institutional and political fabric of the Member States has not yet been fully fully generated. No European legislation should therefore be interpreted in such a way as to restrict the activity of whistleblowers. The latter play a leading role in the fight against corruption and their work is of fundamental importance in preventing or uncovering illegal acts. It is essential that the European Union insists on combating the crime of association and that, within the framework of a genuine and comprehensive European anti-corruption strategy, efforts and resources are concentrated on combating money laundering, corruption and trafficking in human beings.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, EUR 70 million is lost every year from tax evasion and tax avoidance by multinationals. An important element of the Union's wrong political line is the fact that large enterprises in high-tax countries pay on average 30% less tax than small and medium-sized enterprises. A prime example is Greece. Multinationals operating in the country manage to avoid paying taxes, resort to tax havens such as Luxembourg, while at the same time small and medium-sized enterprises close one after the other, since lenders now impose unbearable taxation.  In addition, OLAF's role should be redefined in order to make tax evasion and avoidance more effective and to be hit. Finally, in order for the European Union to contribute to the fight against tax evasion, it must cease to rely on the famous OECD standards, which, as we know, allow the existence of grey areas, thus facilitating tax evasion and avoidance of multinationals.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: " Mr. President, the fight against corruption always, everywhere and constantly. I support this report, because it targets what we want: to try to root out corruption in the public services of the European Union. I want to take this opportunity to underline the strong fight against corruption that has been under way in Croatia for years. We need to highlight positive experiences. The work of USKOK, the work of THE DORH, the work of the Ministry of Interior in Croatia means the eradication of corruption, and at a high level.  And I think it's important that these things are also found in the reports, because we know what southeast Europe means and possible corruption at high levels in various countries and candidate countries. It's written about, it's talked about, but I want to warn here that the very ongoing fight against corruption can only be effective, if we start it from the highest levels, and in this case it is the European Union.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament, through Mr Ferrara's report, rekindles the spotlight on a phenomenon, corruption, which has expanded its areas of influence beyond national borders. The CRIM Committee has helped to bring the debate on the fight against corruption to the international stage, providing clear indications on the legislative actions to be taken. But those answers that we expect from the Union can only be found on the basis of a common definition of organised crime, which is essential if existing and future legislative instruments are to be effective. Today we are operateed, not only from the point of view of defining the case, but also from the point of view of the provisions to combat the phenomenon that are even absent in some countries, which makes it more difficult to combat organised crime and corruption. I am convinced that this issue needs to be addressed in the context of cooperation in criminal matters within the Union by working on the mutual recognition of confiscation and seizure orders. And in order to strike at the real centre of interest of organised crime, the most concrete action is the freezing and confiscation of assets from crime, although unfortunately today many States have not yet transposed the relevant 2014 directive.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The rapper has reason to draw attention to the importance of preventing organised crime and corruption from being incorporated into the legal order and, of course, the economy of each state. It must be seen, however, that the current European system of laws and instruments cannot deal with the phenomenon of corruption being made systemic by a particular political regime or government in order to be in its own power and in order to enrich leaders personally, entrapment of self-serving legislation, as if legitimising the quasi-state corruption net.  Today, in the most obvious way, Hungary of the European Union suffers from this, to which the EU legal order cannot find a meaningful answer. For example, OLAF in vain investigates and uncovers a corruption case involving European funds, if it is to be transferred to the national authority or prosecutor's body whose head may be personally benefiting from the crimes through his kinship.  The setting up of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is, of course, an important and urgent task that can partly respond to such legal challenges, but only joint action by Member States, assuming the full unity and political determination of the European Council, can be effective against such governments.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I thank Laura Ferrara for this follow-up to the 2013 resolution on crime, reiterating her call for a European action plan to combat organised crime, corruption and money laundering. It is not enough to adopt legislation and ratify treaties, we need a concerted plan between the Commission and the Member States, of a multidisciplinary and holistic nature, involving the various anti-crime agencies, but also the administrations of the Member States, parliaments and civil society.  Mutual trust must be fostered and cross-border cooperation procedures need to be expedite. We demand the publication of the second EU-anti-corruption report, which has not yet been scheduled. Monitoring of the report's recommendations should be integrated into the recommendations of the European Semester.  On the other hand, the institutions of the European Union themselves must undergo an integrity assessment. The Union's joining of the Group of States Against Corruption (GRECO) must move forward as soon as possible.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Laura Ferrara, for this report and all the shadows and associated committees for their contribution. The Commission has closely followed the discussions, as well as the work of the Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money-Laundering in the past and the Parliament resolution that followed. It was a source of inspiration for the Commission’s European agenda on security last year. The Agenda on Security identifies three priorities: the fight against terrorism and radicalisation, the fight against organised crime, and the fight against cybercrime. We must continue to move ahead on all three priorities of the Agenda on Security, and your report points up some of the key actions. The Commission, together with Parliament and the Council, have made significant progress on key files relevant for the important areas covered by the report. To name but a few: the adoption of the European Union PNR Directive and adoption of the new European Union Data Protection Package in April earlier this year; the new Europol regulation adopted in May; and the new CEPOL regulation providing for better opportunities to train law enforcement that entered into force in July 2016. Good progress has been made on the Commission’s proposal of last year for a directive on combatting terrorism, and we should be able to reach an agreement before the end of this year. The Action Plan on Wildlife Trafficking adopted in February this year and, last but not least, advancing negotiations on a European Public Prosecutor’s Office to defend the financial interests of the European Union, which will enable Eurojust to focus on the fight against terrorist threats or other serious organised crimes. There is not enough time to comment on each recommendation of the report at hand. Therefore, let me stress the ongoing and planned work in support of some of them. On money laundering: the fight against terrorist financing and money laundering is a high priority for the Commission. A new proposal to reinforce the fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive was tabled on 5 July 2016. As announced in the Action Plan on Strengthening the Fight against Terrorist Financing, we would propose by the end of the year a number of legislative proposals, such as a proposal for a directive on criminal offences and sanctions for money laundering, a proposal on illegal cash movement, a proposal on mutual recognition of confiscation and freezing orders of criminal assets to ensure efficient cross-border cooperation. On the links between organised crime and terrorism, the Commission Action Plan on Terrorist Financing, adopted on 2 February 2016, acknowledges the close link between terrorist financing and organised crime. It announces a wide range of measures to cut terrorists off from their sources of revenue and to trace them through financial activities. On the call for the European Union framework on corruption, the Commission takes very seriously the fight against corruption and will continue to work with Member States’ authorities, including on experience-sharing in relation to integrity policies. This goes in parallel with our work in the framework of the European Semester of Economic Governance. At this stage the Commission is working with Member States to follow up and take forward the conclusions of the first anti—corruption report and will inform Parliament by the end of the year how the Commission sees this work progressing. To conclude, the Commission welcomes the report and will take its recommendations closely into account. We will continue to update Parliament and the Council twice a year, as foreseen in the European Agenda on Security.
