name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. – I am very pleased that Laura Ferrara's report takes into account the serious risks of criminal organisations infiltrating the social, economic, business, political and institutional structure of nation states. Criminal organisations often have a lot of money at their disposal, which they can channel, for example, towards funding election campaigns by prominent politicians. If the same donors often act as donors to the election campaigns of the same politicians, there will automatically be a debt of gratitude to the recipients of the money towards their supporters. Election campaign funders may expect back favors from the political parties they support and the candidates they have passed. In return, the services may be the preparation of preferred legislation, sectoral tax breaks, effective town planes, special interests, the best trading venues, etc. It is therefore very important that all political election funding is as transparent as possible.  In Finland, the Electoral Finance Act was reformed a few years ago. It did not become complete, as numerous major election campaigns are still completely in the dark. For example, only the 13 elected MEPs and the 7 candidates remaining in the reserve are submitted to the authorities of the election funding notification for the 2014 European Elections. In Finland, this means that of the 251 candidates, only 20 submit an election funding declaration. At the same time, large-time election campaigns are completely obscured by the publicity, in which, according to press reports, more than EUR 100 000 is spent. As a rule, the financiers of election campaigns remain a secret. The same problem also applies to parliamentary elections. In this context, it should be borne in mind that candidates with long political careers usually stand as candidates in the European Parliament and parliamentary elections. Many of them have participated in local and national politics, so they often also have influence in decision-making.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. – Organised crime, corruption and money laundering pose a threat not only to the freedom of economic activity and competitiveness, but above all the security and freedom of all citizens. If we want to successfully counter these threats, both at European and national level, we must no longer delay appropriate measures.  Given the cross-border dimension of criminal groups, we need a uniform definition of crime and close cooperation between national authorities and European Union agencies. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, independent of national governments and EU institutions, is a real step towards a more effective fight against corruption.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Marie-Christine Vergiat, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on human rights and migration to third countries (2015/2316(INI)) (A8-0245/2016).

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank in particular the shadow rapporteurs who accompanied me on this report, their assistants and advisers to the groups, as well as Marion, my own colleague, without whom this report could not have been done. We have been working on it for almost a year, their support has been invaluable to me despite the vicissitudes we have been through, the worst of which has been what I would call the test of languages. In the DROI sub-committee, translations are partly entrusted to external services, which must be relatively expensive; we should expect a service that has been up to the task. But it was a horror. We discovered that some of them were automatic translations. That is why, Mr President, I urge the ad hoc bodies of the European Parliament to investigate this matter.  This report deals with human rights and migration in third countries and therefore does not deal with eu migration policies. Our Parliament has reported on this subject, that of Mrs Metsola and Mrs Kyenge, which was adopted by a large majority, and is drawing up another report on external policies. We therefore focused on the situation in third countries, with the desire to put migration in its global context.  The report highlights the evolution of migration policies, which are increasingly globalised but also regionalised, and their increasingly complex and complex causes: 244 million international migrants, or 3.3% of the world's population compared to 2.9% in 1990; 80% of movements are now taking place between countries with common borders, and increasingly South-South. Most of the world's countries today are countries of origin, transit and destination, including in Europe. These migrations are increasingly affecting women and children, particularly isolated minors and, therefore, vulnerable people who are entitled to special protection on the increasingly dangerous migration routes. They are also increasingly graduates: already 59 million in 2010, and Africa is paying the heaviest price for this brain drain. The issue of refugees has a special place in this report. The number of uprooted, refugee and displaced persons now stands at 65 million according to the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees, with a 10% increase in one year, mainly in the number of displaced people.  In our proposals, we wanted to start from respect for human rights, as they are recognised and protected by international conventions, and to see how the European Union, in its policies of partnership with third countries, can act for better respect for human rights, including by setting an example on its territory and by enforcing ad hoc international conventions.  The International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Their Family Members has not been signed by any EU Member State. All migrants have rights, regardless of their situation, as the UN Special Rapporteur on Migrants regularly says. Leaving respect for human rights means, for example, refusing forced readmissions of migrants to countries where they are at risk of ill-treatment and torture; refuse collective expulsions and refoulements that are contrary to international law; respect the right to family reunification and the right to leave a country, including its own, and to be able to return to it in all countries of the world.  These are just a few examples. Such a wish may seem wishful thinking. Some here say that this report would be too progressive. We have taken the majority of the view in the Committee on Foreign Affairs that the European Union should do more in this area, working with its main partners to implement legislation that respects the rights of migrants, starting with the right to asylum.  It seems to us that the IEDDH is a good instrument for moving forward and that it is time to adopt specific guidelines for migrants' rights. We all know that migration issues are becoming increasingly important in the European Union's dialogues with third countries. We also know that a growing proportion of these policies are beyond The control of Parliament. This is why this report proposes, among other things, to evaluate and monitor all agreements and funds in this area, starting with the EU-Turkey agreement and the Khartoum and Rabat processes. Many other topics are covered in this report, I cannot elaborate on them and I regret it. I will end, once again, by thanking all those and, above all, all those - since the vast majority of the shadow rapporteurs were women who contributed to it.

name: Le Président. –
text: Ms. Vergiat, I will answer the question you asked. The translation problem was known to all, but I will also inform the chair of your request, namely to check again what happened.  On-demand interventions

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, europe's exceptional wave of migration requires urgent, concrete responses in line with the seriousness of the situation: it is time for the Member States of the Union to work to give Europe a strategic horizon, promoting an integrated European policy on migration. Most of these people are forced to flee their country because of conflicts, persecution, human rights violations and situations of poverty, and they are often also forced to suffer various kinds of violence on their way to transit countries. It is essential to improve the exchange of good practice with third countries by providing training for humanitarian workers, so that they can more effectively identify the peculiarities, backgrounds and various experiences of migrants, in particular the most vulnerable. In short, if the European Union really wants to tackle the problem of migration properly and coherently, it must be able to build a genuine common partnership with third countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, it is a given that in the first half of this century we will experience unprecedented population movements. The so-called charity that leads people to live in unsuitable camps, such as the Aegean islands or the Calais Jungle, is in fact inhumane and serves only the social dumping attempted by multinationals. That is why the ineffective and unfair Dublin III rules must be changed here and now. In particular, the provisions on a country of first entry, which the German Government wishes to implement again, now that it is collecting the bill for its irresponsible immigration policy, an immigration policy whose burden it is trying to load on Greece by returning refugees from Germany, must be repealed immediately. So she plans, since in Greece she always finds a willing government of her hand, a government that has just realized, a year later, that relocations are not being implemented. And all this, while some are trying to create a climate of de facto cancellation of the written agreement on relocations. Therefore, we must demand relocations here and now for refugees and migrants and an equal distribution within the European Union. The Greek people should not pay for the confrontations and short-sighted policy of the Member States of the Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, what I want to highlight from this report is the fact that along with migration and migrants, we have a key problem of brain drain from poor, developing countries. It is the permanent destruction of knowledge, the destruction of a country when young people and educated people, they do not have to be just young, they leave these countries and we will only feel these repercussions. This will create additional problems and additional gaps in these countries.  I know that the report is not related to the current situation regarding the migrant policy of the European Union, but I want to emphasize another good experience that Croatia has in relations with both Serbia and others on the Western Balkans route, but I want to protest against the relifting of the wire on the border between Croatia and Slovenia.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the majority of this European Parliament is continuing its action to launder the responsibilities and consequences of European Union policies in the phenomena of migration.  Internally, the very serious humanitarian crisis with hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing hunger, misery, persecution and war is intensified as a result of your policies of austerity and impoverishment from abroad.  It hides the role of the EU, the US and NATO in destabilising the Middle East and North Africa, including by imposing war and destruction. The defence of Fortress Europe, the militarisation of the humanitarian response, the policy of return and externalisation of borders, the criminal European migration policy that lifts walls of shame and keeps tens of thousands of refugees trapped in the most deplorable conditions and that leaves thousands of dead in the Mediterranean. Racist and xenophobic policies that fuel the far right and fascism in Europe.  The European Union is now an international reference, a reference in the violation of international law and human rights.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, for me the most important accent on the report of Madam Vergiat is that it is based on the human rights-based approach to migration: it sees migrants as rights holders, and it equally emphasises our needs to respect our international obligations. The second most important – and timely – point is that development cooperation should not be conditional on cooperation on migration-related issues, and I believe that we are now witnessing a very dangerous tendency in the EU financing instruments, which more and more divert aid towards security and towards preventing migration. Unfortunately we are witnessing this in many EU funding instruments at the moment, and this has to be dealt with. Lastly, I would like to say that Madam Vergiat also made a reference to another report which is coming from the Foreign Affairs Committee. I do not understand why we have to produce another report after this one.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I actually asked to speak on the previous point, Mrs Ferrara's report. However, well, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mrs Vergiat on the good work she has done, which is a work that is added to others who have already come out to the LIBE Committee on immigration, work that has been approved, work also supported by the committee which, unfortunately, has never been resolved in any concrete way. And we, even today, after so many debates and after so many acts adopted, always find ourselves with the same problem: with the inability to have unambiguous decisions, as the European Union, and thus suffering the decisions of the individual States. Having said that, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, allow me to congratulate the rapporteur on this comprehensive, balanced and deep analysis of the issue of human rights and migration in third countries. No state or organisation can escape from its obligations under international human rights law to protect and ensure respect for the human rights of migrants, irrespective of their status. We live in a world of seven billion people, with dramatic demographic imbalances, where inequalities are still growing. Migration is here to stay. Migration is the new normal and is now an integral part of our political dialogue with partners, very much in line with the global strategy.  It took a while before Europe accepted its responsibilities, but we are finally doing so. Since 2015 our vessels have saved hundreds of thousands of lives in the Mediterranean. Operation Sophia is disrupting the traffickers’ networks and bringing the smugglers to justice.  In Turkey, in Lebanon and in Jordan we are helping over half a million Syrian children go back to school. The protection of the most vulnerable – the women and children – is at the core of our action in each and every initiative we take. We remain the largest development donor and humanitarian actor. We are, despite criticism, leading by example.  Faced with so much human suffering, we need to respond and we are responding. But we know there is no quick fix to the issue of migration. Our new Partnership Framework (PF) approach reflects just this fact. It is an ambitious and innovative comprehensive approach, fully embedding migration in our overall foreign policy. It is not, as some wrongly believe, only about return or readmission. It is also about countering migrant smuggling and, not least, addressing the root causes of migration. The approach, being tailor-made and holistic, uses all our high-level instruments and leverage to achieve our goals. In fact it represents a new methodology based on genuine partnership.  The partnership addresses everything from security, return, readmission, resilience and job creation to infrastructure, investments and border management. First of all the PF approach, well received by our partners, has created a positive momentum in our dialogue with the countries in question. They do not see it either as us imposing a unilateral agenda; they do not see it as return becoming the only objective of our cooperation; and, rightly so, because the PF approach is indeed about mutually beneficial partnership and it marks a new way of engaging with our partner countries. The results we see are twofold, both in terms of better understanding European Union priorities and willingness to cooperate in practice and in terms of the specific tangible outcomes as you will have seen in the report of the EUCO.  Of course we do not operate in a political vacuum and European Union action must be seen as part of the bigger picture. The United Nations migration-related events during the UN General Assembly gave high visibility and great political momentum to the migration dossier. The New York Declaration for Refugees and Migrants, adopted at the United Nations Summit on 19 September 2016 by all 193 United Nations Member States, forms an important step in providing for a global political framework to address large movements of refugees and migrants in all aspects. We are pleased to see the notion of responsibility-sharing and the importance of international cooperation in response to migration and refugee flows reflected in the outcome. The establishment of a global compact for refugees and a global compact for safe, orderly and regular migration in the coming two years will be an important next step in moving this important agenda forward. The outcome documents closely reflect the European Union priorities and policies. We reaffirm our commitment to ensuring effective implementation of the political declaration and reaffirm our engagement in the upcoming negotiation of the global compact for migration, to be concluded by 2018.  The European Union was able to transmit a positive narrative and show in New York that it has done more than anyone else to address migratory challenges, as well as to demonstrate its commitment towards the principle of global responsibility-sharing through the partnership framework approach, supported by the new innovative European External Investment Plan. We shall now capitalise on this positive momentum and continue to show a strong, united European Union position also in the follow-up and the shaping of the future two global United Nations compacts. All Member States therein also expressed their intention to expand the number and ranges of legal powers available for refugees to be admitted to or resettled in their territory. The Union Resettlement Framework the Commission proposed could facilitate this. This is about developing a harmonised approach to resettlement at European Union level, to provide safe pathways to Europe for people in need of protection, replacing irregular and dangerous migrant crossings and preventing the smugglers from taking advantage of the most vulnerable.  The contributions of each Member State under the annual Union resettlement plan will depend on Member States’ contribution and engagement in the committee. We need the full support of Member States on this. We also need a robust asylum system that will be able to face, not only the challenges of today, but also those in the years to come. Keeping the status quo of our asylum system was not an option. The Commission has put all the elements on the table to reform it. Now it is time for the co-legislators to show their commitment to finding a long-term sustainable solution. The inclusion of migration in the recently adopted 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda is therefore an important milestone. In this context the European Union continues to promote a development-oriented approach towards forced displacement. We want to increase the self-reliance and resilience of refugees in their host communities with the aim of ending dependence on humanitarian aid. Facilitating migration and improving migration policies, as called for in the 2013 Sustainable Development Goals, will allow livelihoods to be improved and will enhance access for refugees to education, job markets, health and housing.  As set out in the European Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015-2019 and in line with the global approach to migration and mobility in the European Agenda on Migration, the European Union and its Member States are committed to enhancing human rights safeguards in all migration and mobility dialogues and cooperation frameworks with third countries and migration-related agreements, processes and programmes.  In line with the European Union Action Plan, the European Union also continues to address the issue of statelessness in relations with priority countries, namely speaking out on situations of statelessness that manifest an immediate and human rights problem and supports the UNHCR’s mandate and activities. Migration and the fight against terrorism remain overwhelmingly the main priorities for European Union action, as confirmed at the informal GAC of 24-25 July this year.  The updated European Union Syria/Iraq regional strategy includes important projects in the fields of humanitarian aid, resilience and stabilisation. It calls for the respect of human rights and accountability, peace-building, gender and minority issues and condemns violations of international humanitarian law, the atrocities, killings and human rights abuses that Daesh is perpetrating.  Within the Gender Action Plan GAP II in European Union external relations for the period 2016-2020, gender is placed at the centre of all forms of European Union external relations. It commits the European Union to implementing actions ensuring girls’ and women’s physical and psychological integrity, promoting their economic and social rights. Together with like-minded partners, the European Union will work for the elimination of all forms of violence against women, including sexual and gender-based violence in conflict and for ending impunity. All perpetrators must be brought to justice. As Ms Vergiat rightly pointed out, access to effective remedies for victims of migration-related human rights abuses is an issue on which further progress is still required. In this context, I would like to point out that the right to effective remedy is one of the issues dealt with in the new regulation on the European Border and Coast Guard. This regulation respects fundamental rights and observes the principles recognised by Articles 2 and 3 of the TEU and reflected in the Charter. In particular, it seeks to ensure full respect for human dignity, liberty and security. Return of irregular migrants who do not have the right to stay in the European Union to their home countries in full respect of the principle of non-refoulement is an essential part of the European Union’s comprehensive efforts to address migration.  In the implementation of the European Union Action Plan on return, the European Union seeks to be compliant with international human rights standards, in particular the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, the 1951 United Nations Refugee Convention and its 1967 Protocol.  A holistic approach to migration and the cross-cutting principle of non-discrimination are the conditions for the effective respect of the human rights of migrants. Our community needs to be based on integration and diversity and on the inclusion of social, cultural, linguistic and religious minorities. Xenophobia, discrimination, violence and hate speech have no place. Let me thank the honourable Members once again for this important contribution to the debate on human rights and migration in third countries and for your excellent report.

text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 25 October, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The migration crisis is characterised by dynamism, requires flexibility and the ability to modify our policy. Today I am pleased to see a change in the original position of Germany and the other Western European countries, which have recognised the naivety of their first disastrous moves: uncritical admission of any number of migrants and the push for a programme of forced relocation of refugees to all EU countries. It is better late than never – although Poland, the Czech Republic or Hungary should hear an apology today from those who even a year ago called us 'egoists' who 'did not mature into Europe'. Against this background, the report submitted is amazed by its staleness. The rapporteur does not distinguish between refugees and economic migrants, calls for far-off EU interference in member states' legal systems, promotes the need for 'legal migration routes' and criticises the readmission mechanism at EU borders, calling for 'priority to be given to voluntary returns over forced return'. Thus, the rapporteur actually calls for the EU to invite as many migrants to its territories as it wants to come here, and to provide them with social care, education and work.  The ECR Group cannot sign off on such prudence. We express our solidarity with those who are forced to leave their country because of conflicts, persecution or extreme poverty – but the solutions to the ongoing crisis proposed by the rapporteur are a step backwards and show that the warning example of the 'Jungle' in Calais has taught some.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: Written. – Slowly but surely, we have seen in recent months that the priorities of European foreign policy are shifting. While the protection of human rights and the strengthening of the rule of law are important principles in our cooperation with third countries, the focus now seems to be shifting more and more towards stopping migration. That is why I call on the Commission and our Foreign Ministers not only to look at our foreign policy with anti-migration glasses, but to show solidarity with the countries in the region that have taken in millions of refugees. For example, Europe must fulfil its humanitarian duty by providing the most vulnerable refugees in those countries with a safe and legal route to the EU through large-scale resettlement. Not as a reward for the country in question, but because of the bitter necessity.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Ignazio Corrao, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on corporate liability for serious human rights violations in third countries (2015/2315(INI)) (A8-0243/2016).

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, with this report, the European Parliament is called upon to take a position on an urgent issue and to initiate a regulatory process leading to concrete and effective responses in this area. The issue of corporate responsibility for serious human rights violations in third countries, still governed by ineffective rules, touches on many of the many fundamental human rights, such as the protection of health and the environment or the rights of workers, children and women.  One of the main objectives we have set ourselves in this report is to ensure that urgent, coherent, continuous and effective action is taken at all levels, effectively addressing the legal problems arising from the multinational dimension of companies and their work. This is due, among other things, to the frequent uncertainty about the allocation of responsibility for human rights violations, and it is precisely from this that impunity for the perpetrators of these violations all too often descends. The report that I am presenting to the House today and which has seen me engaged over the last year is calling loudly for the introduction of binding rules that reaffirm the duty of companies to respect human rights everywhere and in any case. It calls for the introduction of rules reaffirming the obligation for States to protect, within their own jurisdiction, natural persons who have suffered or may suffer human rights violations, even when they are carried out outside their territory. We therefore call on the Member States to establish clear rules to ensure that companies domiciled on their territory, which in any case operate within their jurisdiction, respect human rights in all their activities and in every country and context in which they operate.  We strongly reiterate that, where serious human rights violations are complained of, Member States must guarantee victims access to effective redress, as called for several times by all NGOs and all representatives of civil and academic society that we have involved during the preparatory phase of the report. We also call for the creation of minimum criminal rules defining cases and sanctions for cases of human rights violations by companies with a transnational dimension. Finally, I would like to highlight one of the many measures at no cost, but extremely effective, proposed in the report signed by me. I am referring to the creation of a European 'abuse free' label which could represent a major change in corporate culture. A trade mark granted to undertakings which voluntarily request it and which therefore decide to undergo effective and stringent controls carried out by independent bodies. In this way, consumers will be able to make a conscious choice.  All these issues have been the focus of a long, constructive and passionate debate between the political parties. I am proud that a report on a potentially divisive subject was adopted in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Almost unanimously. In this regard, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs once again for their valuable contribution and for their willingness in recent months to participate in the drafting of a good parliamentary report on such an important subject.  Finally, I would like to thank all the activists of the 5-star Movement for all the citizens who wanted to participate in the drafting of this report. Thanks to the Rousseau operating system, a system that allows members to participate in political life on the net, many citizens have had the opportunity to get to know this draft report and to express their opinion. All their comments received have been carefully examined and some of them have been transformed into amendments signed by me and have been incorporated into the text voted on in committee. It is direct democracy, the citizen who becomes an institution and participates in the construction of a law or an own-initiative report. This report will be voted on tomorrow by this House in the hope that it will be only the beginning of a real path towards an effective and concrete fight against human rights violations committed by companies in third countries.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Corrao's report is an important voice in the international debate on corporate social responsibility. This debate is not the first time, and in this House, that this debate is bearing fruit, as the Guidelines on Business and Human Rights were unanimously adopted by the UN five years ago. At the moment, the difficult process of implementing these guidelines is underway and we will agree that the Union, together with the companies operating, is a kind of leader here. In the wake of this resolution, an open intergovernmental working group on a legally binding international instrument in this area has started, and I think that, in principle, international solutions should be positively assessed, not just European, because then we can only talk about their effective functioning. It should also be noted that one measure should not be sized for all categories of enterprises, that this statement 'one size fits all' here does not fit, that the largest multinationals have more responsibilities here than small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, I would say periodically, cases of human rights violations in third countries by multinational companies and, among them, European groups, are discovered; This is particularly serious, because since the European Union is founded, among others, on respect for human rights, European companies should set a global example in the field of corporate responsibility. I agree with the document. I only regret that the text did not go into even more detail on the subject of the exploitation of child labour, which is still widespread in some regions of the world. An Amnesty International study shows, for example, that 16 multinationals selling electronic products are customers of companies that produce batteries using cobalt from mines in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where some 40 000 children work. It is therefore necessary for all companies, European and non-European, to exercise so-called 'due diligence' and for all countries to lay down clear rules for respect for human rights in business activities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, human rights violations by companies are of global concern. More and more companies are moving their factories to third countries, taking advantage of cheap labour and non-existent labour rights. Respect for human rights is a moral duty and legal obligation of companies and their management, regardless of their place of activity. There are few phenomena where international companies pride themselves on so-called corporate social responsibility, while at the same time profiting from low operating costs due to the exploitation of child labour.  The protection of human rights must be a priority for all Member States and the Union. However, we note that, despite the communication from the Committee on Corporate Social Responsibility since 2011, several Member States have not yet established national policy frameworks to promote corporate responsibility or published their plans for business and human rights. If the European Union wants more corporate responsibility, it must stop maintaining corporate irresponsibility and hide behind its finger. It should combat social dumping and tax avoidance and restrict the activity of businesses that do not respect labour protection rules.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, responsible business conduct can no longer be ignored, that is for sure, and I believe that the discussion on sustainable supply chains is here to stay, and the EU also must act accordingly. Last month we discussed the case of Andy Hall, a British human rights defender and defender of migrants’ rights in Thailand, and we saw that companies are ready to take responsibility, and they should be grateful for researchers and civil society organisations who inform them about wrongdoings and breaches of human rights in their supply chains. We have very good examples: the UK law on modern slavery is excellent, the French initiative on due diligence on supply chains as well. I would like to ask Commissioner Cañete if the EU is coming out with the promised action plan on responsible business conduct that we have been awaiting for months and months.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, by addressing a relevant and fair issue, the report is based on a wrong premise, that it is possible to humanise capitalism. It is in the nature of the capitalist system, in its predatory and exploitation aspect, that the root of the problem is.  Large companies and multinationals exploit, directly or indirectly, in the name of profit and ably, the natural resources of the peoples of third countries, without any itching of committing the most heinous environmental crimes against the populations or of inhumanely exploiting workers.  References to the need to increase workers' rights, regulation of workers, better distribution of wealth or the sovereign role of states in protecting workers, peoples and resources from the exploitation of large monopolistic capital are unnoticed or there are no references to the need to increase workers' rights, to regulate work, to better distribute wealth or to the sovereign role of states in protecting workers, peoples and resources from the exploitation of large monopolistic capital. A reference that is also absent, that of the need for trade policies that do not constitute new neocolonial instruments, rather respect the sovereignty of states and are based on the effective mutual benefit between equal parties.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2016 workers' rights in the world were weakened, not only because of the deterioration in working conditions, but also because of the restriction on freedom of expression and assembly. An issue, that of the exploitation of work, involving the responsibilities of governments and companies, the latter often guilty of very serious violations of workers' rights. Millions of workers in the Middle East and Africa live in conditions of slavery. In many countries outside Europe, workers do not benefit from the right to strike, are restricted in freedom of expression and assembly and are often victims of physical violence and threats. The European Union must work to ensure that trade and human rights can both be strengthened. The business community, particularly in third countries, is obliged to respect human rights in all forms. The Union must be able to establish a trade and investment policy with third countries based not only on market needs, but also on ethical values.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all allow me to congratulate Mr Corrao for this comprehensive, balanced, deep analysis of the issue of corporate social responsibility in third countries. As the Council Conclusions of June 2016 show, business and human rights is a priority for the European Union. This year the Council also adopted Conclusions on Responsible Global Value Chains. As set out in the European Union Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015 – 2019, the European Union’s Member States are committed to make an advance on business and human rights. Corporate respect for human rights is indispensable. As you do in your report, we consistently call on all business enterprises, both transnational and domestic, to integrate human rights due diligence into their operations, to better identify, prevent, and mitigate human rights risks. The European Union supports the United Nations Guiding Principles. The proper implementation is good for the European Union and good for business. The European Union Member States have taken the lead internationally on developing and adopting national action plans to implement the Guiding Principles. As you rightly point out, Mr Corrao, access to effective remedies for victims of business-related human rights abuses is an issue on which further progress is still required. In this context, I am pleased that the European Union Fundamental Rights Agency is currently working on an expert opinion on how to lower barriers for access to remedy at the European Union level. I also welcome the recent adoption of the Council of Europe’s Committee of Ministers’ Recommendations on Human Rights and Business with a particular focus on access to remedy. The European institutions and Member States need to implement these recommendations. Furthermore, the European Union welcomes the initiative on enhancing accountability and access to remedy of the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. This may provide best practices that can be implemented at the European Union and Member State level, including on improved cooperation between states in cross-border cases. As regards our external policy, in line with the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy, the EEAS and the Member States will continue to raise business and human rights in their contacts with third countries. This also includes human rights dialogues, as well as dedicated seminars and financial support aimed at the development of the national action plans on business and human rights. Also important is the need to build capacity, both within European Union delegations and Member States’ embassies, to work effectively on business and human rights issues, including providing support to human rights defenders working on corporate accountability. As regards the legally-binding instrument on business and human rights, the European Union has followed carefully the preparation of the Intergovernmental Working Group in Geneva. Since the start, we made our participation in the working group dependent on two principled conditions: first, ensuring that the scope of the discussion is not limited to transnational corporations, and second, making sure that the implementation of UNGPs is not undermined. This position was supported by a range of countries across different regions and by a number of civil society organisations. In the run-up to the next meeting of the Intergovernmental Working Group on 24 October, the European Union has been actively engaged with the Chair-rapporteur and with all regional political groups with a view to addressing these issues and finding a solution that would entitle the European Union to provide a more active contribution to the works of the group. I am pleased to inform the honourable Members that the European Union requests have been met by the Chair-rapporteur. The European Union therefore took the decision to participate in the Intergovernmental Working Group. The debate is now now open, and your contributions on how to improve the international legal framework for the protection of human rights in the context of corporate activities are all the more precious. There was a direct question from Ms Hautala. What I can tell you is that the preparation of a paper on the Commission policy document on corporate social responsibility is currently ongoing. Finally, let me thank you again for this important contribution to the debate on business and human rights and for an excellent report that represents a reference for our work.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 25 October, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. – This report, in which I worked as shadow rapporteur on behalf of S&D, is a clearly progressive report, which seeks to respond to the challenges posed in the field of human rights by the transnationalisation of business activity, including european companies, for which we obviously have an increased responsibility.  It calls for the systematic inclusion of human rights clauses in trade treaties concluded between the EU and third countries.  It calls for the global implementation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.  It calls for greater EU engagement in the binding international treaty being negotiated at the UN.  It stresses that multinationals should be legally held accountable where human rights abuses result from their operations in third countries, and that they have a duty to compensate victims of such abuses. It incorporates high-relevance recommendations, such as the creation of an EU certificate for products whose production has not involved human rights abuses.  At my suggestion, it was found in the report that such a certificate positively discriminates against companies, enabling them to benefit.  In short, this excellent report presents very valid reflections and proposals to address some negative effects of globalisation, and I believe that this House deserves the support of this House.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by András Gyürk, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the EU strategy on liquefied natural gas and gas storage (2015/2059(INI)) (A8-0278/2016).

name: András Gyürk
text: Artist. - Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, my fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Allow me to present to you the report on liquefied natural gas and storage, in full of my reporting obligation. I am proud to say that, together with the shadow reporters, we have succeeded in developing a comprehensive framework that will be able to move the development of European gas markets forward in the long term and support security of supply.  This strategy is not standing on its own, but is integrated into the system built up by parliament's previous decisions. It is in line with the objectives of the Energy Union package and takes into account the other reports of the Gas Winter Package. I believe that such work should only be done in compliance with these frameworks, and we have acted accordingly.  When preparing this report, we had the following objectives in mind: to stimulate competition in the market to drive down consumer prices, to support security of supply by increasing diversification, and, last but not least, to always keep sustainability in mind.  The report goes around a number of important issues, but allow me to highlight those which I believe are the most important of them: first of all, of course, the situation in the vulnerable Member States must be sorted out. It is essential that we show solidarity with Member States that do not have alternative options and are only able to source natural gas from one place. Adequate reservoir capacity can help these countries over time, but the long-term solution can only be source diversification, of which liquefied natural gas can be an excellent tool.  The second major issue is infrastructure. In order to improve the utilization of existing devices, we must first connect isolated networks. The list of priority projects of the European Commission includes investments that would be able to establish these links and resolve the most serious constrictions. In conclusion, in order to really take advantage of existing investments, we must first carry out those that have been missed.  Thirdly, it should be pointed out that the physical infrastructure, the hardware itself, is insufficient without the software. In this case, the software is tariffs, standards, procedures. Their coordination is as important as physical connectivity.  In addition to these issues, we also addressed the role of liquefied natural gas in transport and decarbonisation and the opportunities of the European Union as an active player in the international gas market.  To conclude, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have contributed to this report, in particular the shadow notiers. I believe that without the cooperation of the factions, we would not have been able to achieve so much.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I believe that this report is worth supporting, because the text draws on the motions of all political factions – and including the thought world of each of them, so we can say that this is a real compromise – which is also another sure step towards a common goal, the Energy Union. Thank you so much for your attention.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I really must congratulate and pay fair praise to the rapporteur for this truly comprehensive, effective and holistic report on energy, to my dear colleague, András Gyürk, who has essentially touched not only on the issue of gas, but also more broadly on the issues of the European Union's energy strategy and on the issue of the Energy Union. I adopt and support this report not only because in its energy plans it includes my own country, Cyprus, but also the Mediterranean, which is a very important player today, in order to be able to complete the issue of energy self-sufficiency, energy supply and energy support of the European Union, but, at the same time, because it also proposes solutions with regard to the liquefied natural gas terminal. , as essentially a small country like Cyprus cannot in itself invest and build such a large project and, for this reason, it is addressed to the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is important to use for these projects.  Addressing the Commissioner present here, I would like to point out that now is the opportunity to use the European Fund for Strategic Investments for the European Union's energy self-sufficiency. And the Eastern Mediterranean, like other regions, is offered in this direction. At the same time, in conclusion, I would like to welcome the reference made in the report that the European Union can become a leader in renewable energy sources, make use of 100% of renewable energy sources, fight energy poverty and effectively safeguard this basic human right, that is, energy to be the property of every European citizen.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you, Commissioner. From a small country to another small country – Malta. I would speak from the point of view of Malta because, yes, we do understand that, to reach the EU’s energy and climate targets by 2030 (but most of all provide affordable energy), liquefied natural gas should be considered as an alternative fuel solution, particularly for certain Member States. LNG not only cuts down radically CO2 emissions but is also a transitory link between the current fuel-based system and the futures’ low carbon energy and transport scenarios, including also for vehicles and maritime vessels. Coming from Malta, I believe that there is a clear potential for synergies – which are yet to be exploited – between the gas-rich North African region and the European Union. It is positive that this strategy acknowledges that LNG and gas storage will contribute towards ending energy isolation, which affects Member States, including Malta – more so since it is a key objective of the EU’s Energy Union that all Member States have access to liquid gas markets. This is a mature technology where the global market is still booming, and the EU and its Member States should not stay behind.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, it is time to assess the losses that have been created and initiated by the European Union's ideological policy on the gas market. There are more than 20 terminals, many of which were financed with taxpayers' money, but in the end only 20% of the capacity of these stations is used and some of them do not even work. This is for a very simple reason: liquefied natural gas remains more expensive than other alternatives. The only solution to sufficiently reduce prices could be the massive increase in gas imports from North America, but this is contrary to the ecological values established in the European Union, since the gas comes from the destructive activity of fracking.  Gentlemen of the Commission, you must finally recognise that the primary objective of the development of liquefied natural gas has been and remains geopolitical. This is also the reason for the initial failure of European Union policy. The development of liquefied natural gas infrastructure can be efficient, as long as the European Union abandons its neoliberal ideologies and geopolitical blinders.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I am convinced that finally the only correct solution is the Energy Union, and in this context of course solidarity with countries that have energy problems. I am definitely one of those proponents who sees LNG as something that can solve a number of problems, specifically in the Adriatic.  We know that Croatia has a serious large LNG terminal project on the island of Krk, which, in truth, has been done for two decades not very successful, but I believe that the last steps have been made, what the Commission itself has shown by supporting this project, that finally LNG on Krk will come true. For this, as we know, there is an extraordinary interest of other neighboring states. However, we have to set things up realistically economically, and partly politically, if we want this project to really work.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur András Gyürk on the work he has done. The LNG strategy should contribute to reducing dependence on pipelines and diversifying sources and supply routes to combat energy poverty primarily, but also to enhance energy security. To achieve this, however, it is important to exploit domestic energy sources. We therefore welcome the report's reference to the need to support the exploitation of deposits in the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone and more broadly in the Eastern Mediterranean, as well as the creation of an LNG terminal in Cyprus. It is necessary for this proposal to be heard. And it is necessary, Commissioner, for the Union to give immediate financial and technical support for the implementation of the necessary infrastructures. Equally important is to support countries that are energy islands, such as Cyprus and Malta, in order to lift their energy out of isolation.  Unfortunately, however, the positive proposals in the report are cancelled by the measures being promoted to impose a common energy policy that limits the sovereignty and flexibility of states and makes energy a tool to serve market needs through TTIP agreements. For GUE/NGL, the LNG strategy should enhance national flexibility, promote public infrastructure with environmental standards and ensure the right to equal and cheap access to energy.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr. President, Dear Commissioner Cañete, I take the opportunity to say that I support this European LNG strategy and gas storage. I think this is very important for the transition of the European Union towards a low-carbon society.  However, what I would like to draw attention to is that we have defined some of our objectives by signing the Paris Agreement, that we have incorporated this into the European Parliament resolutions as targets that we should achieve by 2030 with a view to 2050, and that we need to warn Member States that switching to natural gas as a substitute for coal is not the solution, because this is only a 40% reduction in emissions and we will not achieve the targets we have promised , actually signed in the Paris Agreement.  I believe that the regional approach is very important and I fully support it and it is in this context that the LNG terminal on the island of Krk is important for construction because it will finally ensure that the southeast of Europe has a diversification of supply and that it does not depend on just one natural gas supplier. I draw attention that in addition to energy and the transport sector, it is very important to link this LNG strategy with the transport strategy.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Gyürk for her work on this very important strategy and, as rapporteur for her opinion in the Committee on Transport, I obviously could not leave this opportunity to mention the importance of liquefied natural gas for maritime and heavy goods vehicles as an alternative fuel.  It is essential to create a network of supply and storage infrastructure, but not to exclude seaports from the islands, as referred to in the Alternative Fuels Directive.  The solution also involves the construction of small-scale infrastructure and the use of regular cabotage vessels. That is why, as mentioned in this report too, I have proposed the creation of a joint project, blue LNG corridors for the islands, for the outermost regions of the Atlantic, in particular for Madeira and the Azores, and so that ports can be adapted, maritime links work and ships reconversion. I would therefore also ask the Commissioner for special attention and to commit himself to supporting and making funds available for the implementation of this project which is undoubtedly of interest to Portugal but certainly of interest to the European Union.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, liquefied natural gas is a very important component in ensuring diversification and energy security and supporting a sustainable transition to a renewable and clean energy-based model. I was rapporteur in the ENVI Committee and the opinion highlights the optimisation of existing networks, the importance of supporting the energy transition and, in particular, of decarbonising heavy transport and maritime transport. This strategy must be aligned with the Paris Agreement and it is very important to take advantage of LNG for this issue of transport, maritime transport and heavy transport. I would therefore like to stress the recommendation in this report that the Azores archipelago, due to its geographical location, has a fuel station for transatlantic shipping routes and it is also very important that, in its various financing instruments, the European Commission provides for the financing of such projects.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Mr President, energy security, energy efficiency and the lowest price for consumers are indeed the pillars for which we must work. But we must also be realistic. In many Member States, such as my home country of Greece, we are dependent on a single supplier for natural gas and so it is necessary to have greater access to liquefied natural gas. It is also an opportunity to give consumers access to cheap energy as, due to the oversupply of LNG, its price has fallen significantly. At the same time, however, we must immediately create and strengthen supporting pipeline infrastructures that combine all forms of natural gas. One such example, and I would like you to hear it, ladies and gentlemen, is the work of DEPA for Central and Eastern Macedonia and Thrace; a project that can provide natural gas to county capitals, smaller cities, industrial zones, one of the poorest energy regions in Greece and Europe; a 1,128 km project that will expand Greece's energy market by 0.4 billion cubic centimeters and attract investors. We need the support of all the European Union's financial instruments to give Greek consumers cheaper energy.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, first of all congratulations to the rapporteur on this good and indeed comprehensive work. Given the energy needs of the European Union, the aim of reducing dependence on a supplier and geographical diversification and finally the serious security problems that exist, it is imperative to make use of both resources outside the European Union, but in particular - and this is mentioned in the report - domestic natural energy resources and, in particular, deposits located in the Eastern Mediterranean and within the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone.  It is also important to set up a gas liquefaction terminal in Cyprus. Finally, Cyprus provides the possibility of synergies with Israel, Lebanon and Egypt. And the use of the so-called Juncker plan can prioritise a small country such as Cyprus, which is also in economic crisis, to be able to exploit its natural deposits. Finally, Mr President, one final point: Cyprus and Malta are isolated countries and should be helped.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, and thank you for taking us all in the catch-the-eye, because this is a very important topic for us, especially those who come from small countries like mine – Ireland, which is an island. With the exception of the temporary supply of gas from the Corrib gas field, we are totally dependent on our gas coming from one interconnector from the United Kingdom. What is going to happen us if and when the United Kingdom leaves the European Union? For that reason LNG is so important to us, and there are proposals to build a terminal in Shannon, which has been very much helped by many of the far-sighted policies of Commissioner Cañete, and also the good work here of my colleague, Mr Gyürk. Without doubt it is essential for us to diversify supply, secure supply and, of course, also avail of cheaper prices as a result of it. As has been said, we want to be the renewable capital of the world, but at the same time they are intermittent, and gas is the ideal backup to renewables. So it is a win-win, but we have to get LNG into as many countries in Europe as possible.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of a European Union strategy on liquefied natural gas would aim to achieve a rapid transition to a sustainable, safe and competitive energy system and to put an end to dependence on external gas suppliers. In this assessment, however, it is not secondary to consider that the existing LNG infrastructure in the European Union is clearly under-utilised and that gas demand continues to be overestimated. Ex ante impact assessments should be carried out on the actual added value of the construction of new LNG transport and storage infrastructure, taking into account the potential of optimising the efficient and safe use of existing storage infrastructure, including gas storage. I believe that the European Union and its Member States should focus more on renewable resources and improving energy efficiency, seeking to take full advantage of renewable production capacity and limiting investment in new LNG transport and storage infrastructure to the areas of poor interconnection and supply of the most vulnerable Member States.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, liquefied natural gas can play an important role in mitigating the effects of greenhouse gas and in carrying out decarbonisation efforts contemplated in the agreement reached at COP 21, where, as we know, maritime transport has been left out of the equation. This appeal should be considered transitory and should not slow down or replace investments in renewable energy development and the abandonment of fossil fuels, and should question the use of large-scale hydraulic fracturing for natural gas extraction, given the negative environmental effects at the site.  However, I believe that this commitment, as a transitional and forward-looking, can be a solution for Europe that is more in line with the challenges of this century and an opportunity to promote sustained economic development. Therefore, I stress and record as very positive the reference to the development of sea routes in which the Azores archipelago, given its geostrategic location in the centre of the Atlantic, can be a key point in the supply of merchant ships with liquefied natural gas.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Despite the fact that the objectives indicated by the reporter can be more or less agreed with, I consider the sustainability or energy efficiency logic to be very little in it, and I particularly miss the need to base the future on a carbon-free and, if possible, nuclear-free energy use.  At the same time, there are a number of unsettled questions: who can cover the various costs? For example, I do not agree with the report's recommendation that the Union should provide the necessary infrastructure. To give you an example: Hungary, my country, where I come from, at the moment the Orban government has a sentence summarizing its energy policy: buying natural gas from Russians and buying Russian nuclear power plants from Russians on Russian credit. Now this goes against European strategies in a far-reaching way, and as long as the energy mix is referred to as a kind of sacred cow, these strategies have relatively little meaning and effectiveness. However, one recommendation is that, when talking about liquid gas, in this case the origin must be very carefully observed, lest shale gas become this liquid gas.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking this House, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Gyürk, for his important work on this crucial file. The Commission is fully in line with these conclusions and is ready to act upon the specific challenges highlighted in the report. As the report rightly outlines, this study can have a transformative effect on reinforcing our energy security and boosting our competitiveness by providing access to liquid hubs and a diverse range of gas sources. But before I go into some of the detail, I think it is worth recalling some of the principles which underpin our strategy. First, the diversification of the natural gas supply is a strategic objective of the European Union as domestic production declines further down the road. The Commission’s LNG and gas storage strategy aims to exploit the potential of liquefied natural gas and gas storage to make the European Union gas system more diverse and flexible, thus contributing to the key Energy Union objective of a secure, resilient and competitive gas supply. LNG can also bring benefits in terms of competitiveness as gas markets become exposed to more competition from international suppliers. In some cases the impact can be significant, as in the case of Lithuania. Furthermore, LNG also has the potential in some cases to reduce environmental impacts, especially in the transport sector. Let me reiterate: the European Union’s LNG strategy was conceived with our Paris climate commitments in mind. The truth is that natural gas is likely to remain an important source for our energy mix as one possible solution for a flexible energy system which includes responsive generation, demand response, grids and storage. As we work on decarbonising our economy, renewables will become more prominent in the European Union’s energy mix, while gas will maintain its role with around 24-25%, pushing out other more polluting fossil fuels. That is why achieving our goals on diversity of gas supplies in every European Union Member State or liquid competitive markets and in meeting the needs of citizens and industry is of cardinal importance. We pursue this diversification objective on three priority axes: opening the southern gas corridor, developing an east Mediterranean gas hub, and taking the opportunity provided by the positive developments of the global LNG market. These axes together will considerably contribute to increased competition and a downward pressure on European gas prices. We believe that a functioning and fully-integrated liquid market is the best way to achieve our gas security objectives by making the European Union attractive for suppliers and keeping prices under control through enhanced competition. That is why this strategy focuses on completing the internal gas market, both in terms of infrastructure as well as market rules, in order to provide diversification to the most vulnerable regions of the European Union. Now on to some of the specific points raised in the report. We welcome that Mr Gyürk’s report also acknowledges the importance of the established regional high-level groups in these vulnerable regions. It is only through targeted action and cooperation that we can best meet the needs of each region. These same groups are also best placed to discuss the prioritisation of infrastructure projects that can address the particular challenges. There is a successful CESEC high-level group that brings together Member States and Energy Community Countries in central and south-east Europe, has identified six key priority projects and already approve an action plan of regulatory solutions that we propose in our LNG strategy to make them happen. The BEMIP high-level group is working on a similar action plan that we will deliver before the end of the year, but I could also mention the work of the South-West High Level Group in the Iberian Peninslua.  On stranded assets, let me say that we are fully aware of the risks here, given today’s constantly changing environment. We need to be mindful of which infrastructure investment we follow through and should focus on only delivering those infrastructure projects that are absolutely essential to security of supply. This is also what we propose in this strategy. A limited number of key infrastructure mainly aiming at connecting to existing import terminals and a storage capacity and one LNG terminal in south-east Europe that will serve the whole region. Here we rely on the results of existing regional cooperation. The projects put forward in the strategy have all been agreed beforehand under the three high-level groups I mentioned before. On climate and sustainability, I fully support the report’s conclusions. We need to look at both the opportunities and challenges in the LNG value chain. On this point, let me stress that the Commission will work closely with international partners to reduce methane slip in the overall LNG chain. This is absolutely crucial to ensure that the positive aspects of using LNG will not be compromised by the adverse effects of methane slip. As mentioned in the report, we should also highlight the potential of renewable sources of gas, also in the form of liquefied biogas. These sources can often utilise existing infrastructure, extending their useful lifetime further into the future. The strategy also recognises the great potential of LNG in the transport sector, in particular in maritime and heavy road transport, where it can replace more polluting fuels. Mr Gyürk’s report also highlights the potential of small-scale LNG for local industry in islands, where gas can replace oil as a fuel for power generation or feedstock. On storage, let me say that it needs to be able to compete on a level playing field. Operators should be able to easily develop the more flexible products to match market needs. Barriers to cross-border access should be eliminated and real cooperation on the efficient use for both business user and possibility of supply purposes should be stressed. In this regard you will be happy to hear that discussions on the gas tariff network codes have finished and the special role of LNG in the European Union market is well reflected in them. Finally, let me turn to the international aspects rightly given prominence in the report. The study, which foresees the European Union as the second largest LNG importer in the world, will play a proactive role in the international efforts to promote a liquid and transparent global LNG market. We will work with our international partners to promote gas trading rules that lead to more flexibility and the convergence of global gas markets. LNG trade is already a subject in our energy dialogues with important consumers such as Japan and current and future suppliers such as the Gulf countries, the United States and Canada, and this will be a step up in the future. Honourable Members, allow me to finish by once again by thanking the rapporteur and by stressing the importance the Commission attaches to this strategy. It can have a significant impact across all five dimensions of the Energy Union, and I look forward to working with the European Parliament to make that happen.
