name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union's LNG and gas storage strategy is an important step towards improving energy security and stability. I would like to stress that one of the most important challenges facing the European Union under the common energy policy is to ensure that all citizens and economic operators have continuous and competitive access to energy, including natural gas. For years we have been struggling with the problem of differences in gas prices in the various markets of the European Union. In Central Europe, gas prices are up to 23% higher and the market in these countries is too weakly interconnected internally. We cannot talk about energy security when many Member States are dependent on a single supplier, while experiencing problems such as price discrimination or supply disruptions. The key issue solving these problems is the diversification of m.in. gas supply through the use of LNG, as well as the development of transmission and storage infrastructure. I would like to point out that energy security depends not only on market competition, but also on legislation at European Union level and strategic agreements.

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The European strategy for natural gas and LNG should not be based on a replacement of coal with another fossil fuel that continues to emit CO2 and above all methane, more than 80 times worse than CO2 for global warming. The Commission has long sought to impose the use of gas across Europe, as a simple change of fuel, by inflating consumption predictions without taking into account improved energy efficiency or renewable penetration. This has resulted in over-investment in used facilities at 25% of its capacity in Europe. Countries such as Spain have plants that were closed on the same day as their opening. The important climate agreements, ratified by the Union, must be the basis of any energy strategy, where energy efficiency and the use of clean energy must be put before any development of fossil fuel energy sources. Natural gas could be a transitional support for the entry of renewables into Europe's energy mixes, but it will become an impediment to the development of clean energy if it is promoted short-term as a reduction in C02 emissions.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Having an adequate strategy for liquefied natural gas and gas storage is of key importance to Europe’s energy security. Some Member States, such as Lithuania, have rightfully invested in a new LNG terminal, thereby decreasing their dependency on Russian gas, whereas others are wasting money on foolishly increasing their dependency on such an unreliable source. Russia has demonstrated on countless occasions that it is not a reliable partner to the EU and does not hesitate to wield energy as a political weapon. It would be extremely irresponsible to jeopardise our citizens’ wellbeing by subjecting their energy security to the whims of the Kremlin. We must therefore strongly oppose the doubling of the North Stream pipeline. The current pipeline is used in only half of its capacity; therefore, the only reason to double it is to divert all gas transit away from Ukraine in order to further destabilise the country. Furthermore, we currently lack sufficient interconnections for that gas to make its way back to our eastern Member States; North Stream 2 would therefore put them in a much more precarious position. Some of those states are also landlocked, which further impedes their access to LNG brought in by ships.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Isabelle Thomas, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, entitled 'How to harmonise fisheries controls in Europe?' (2015/2093(INI)) (A8-0234/2016).

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on the docks of fishing ports, information is spreading faster than on the airwaves, either to criticise the latest regulations or to comment on the prices of the day's fishing. Listening to the docks often identifies possible policy dysfunctions. However, for several years now, and regardless of the country of the European Union, the same story has been heard everywhere on the docks: the one that says that fisheries control would be less severe in neighbours than at home. While a rumour never meant that there was a substance of truth, its persistence merited further study. I therefore conducted the inquiry with the support of my colleagues in Parliament's Fisheries Committee and prepared an initiative report on that basis. Indeed, this sense of unfairness due to the differentiated application of the regulation according to the country raises the question not only of the effectiveness but also of the credibility of the European Union. The regulation is supposed to apply to everyone and it is not acceptable that it is not the same. Compliance with the rule, however, determines the results of sustainability and modernity of fishing activity. In this report, I wanted to analyze the flaws in regulation and its application, which lead to this sense of injustice. The second purpose of this report is to propose solutions to harmonize the control of the common fisheries policy, which I recall is supposed to be one of the most integrated policies in Europe. I am, of course, delighted by the constructive work carried out in committee, where everyone's contribution has provided an almost complete picture of the situation of control in Europe. I would, of course, particularly thank the shadow rapporteurs. This report emphasizes the chameleon nature of the "control" regulation in the sense that, depending on the colour of the country, it applies differently, whether it is the scope of the control regulation or the procedures and strategies. The report also reveals that each Member State sets up its own monitoring grounds for controllers, that fishermen's training is disparate and that there is not always monitoring training.  The overly limited mandate of the fisheries control agency, whose main role should be, precisely, to harmonize practices, is also highlighted. It therefore seems appropriate to create a European training of controllers and to develop a single benchmark for control.  Training for fishermen should also be strengthened. Procedures should also be Europeanised and the role of the Vigo agency strengthened by increasing its resources and broadening its scope.  It also seems to me urgent that the control procedures be transparent and standardised, and that the different control bodies coordinate within the same geographical area.  But the most serious dysfunction is that Member States can transpose regulation differently because of a large number of optional provisions within the 'control' regulation and the inapplicability of some of them, which can lead to a subjective interpretation of the controllers.  It will therefore be essential to remove the optional mentions and clarify but also to simplify the existing EU legislation at the next revision of the 'control' regulation. Jurisdictional procedures and sanctions are also different across the Union. For the same offence, the penalty may be administrative or criminal in nature. It seems legitimate to implement a regulation in the future where the same sanction will be applied for the same offence and to introduce incentives.  Moreover, the instruments, tools and financial means used to carry out the controls also vary from one Member State to another. In fact, the most urgent point, according to the controllers we have heard from all countries, is the data and the compatibility of the instruments.  The databases used by Member States are not always shared, which is essential for risk assessment and control strategy. I will end with the issue of boating, which will be put to the test during this week's votes. If we are to achieve the adequacy between fishing rights and the state of the fishing resource, it is essential that this activity is also controlled. Let us remember that we are a few steps away from the revision of the Fisheries Control Regulation announced by the Commission. I have no doubt that the recommendations adopted by Parliament will be taken into account in the future Proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I must say I learned an awful lot from listening to the rapporteur, Ms Thomas, and I congratulate her and thank her for what she said, because I have had several queries from fishermen and women in Ireland about the exact issues that she raised. And she explained why it is so: it is because the laws are transposed differently; there are voluntary aspects to it. Training is different for inspectors across Europe; training is different for fishermen; the penalties are different. Now, for what is called a common fisheries policy, that makes absolutely no sense. But it does explain the fact that, in my country at least, many of the fishing communities feel that the inspectorates especially go overboard and that these issues are probably gold-plated at national level. So there is need for harmonisation across Europe, and I think she has put her finger on the exact difficulty we have, and if we do that, then we can have a better and more equal system. I will just give you just one example. Recently dolphins were found dead off the Irish coast with ropes tied onto them, and the feeling is that the big super-trawlers are getting away with it while the smaller people are being pursued.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is really important to create a strategy to make monitoring of fishing activities in Europe more efficient and fairer. As the rapporteur, Mrs Thomas, points out, and which I would like to congratulate on the work done, there are significant differences in the legal approach and the final price between the various Member States and which promote injustice and misunderstanding.  In addition to harmonisation at national level, there are other instruments that could partially mitigate this problem. For example, it is necessary to establish formative proposals based on the European Agenda for Fisheries Control to be used by national and regional pensions. I also find it very interesting to strengthen the use of new technologies and international cooperation, including that of third countries. For all these reasons, I will call for a positive vote on the proposed report and congratulate the rapporteur again.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, ensuring effective control of fishing activities is a prerequisite for ensuring a sustainable exploitation of marine resources, but also for a level playing field between the Union's fleets. In order to ensure this competition and to ensure equality in the treatment of fishermen, the European Union proposes to regulate a common fisheries control regulation.  However, in countries such as Greece, where fishermen are experiencing the consequences of the troika's agricultural memorandum, the Union is far from strengthening the fisheries sector. The tax policies, Mr Vella, imposed by the Commission through the troika are driving coastal fishermen to decline, while the primary sector is increasingly affected. It is therefore necessary for the Union to emphasise the strengthening of the blue economy, the increase in funding in the fisheries sector, and in relation to Greece, Mr Vella, we must finally put a stop to the tax policy which affects the incomes and interests of fishermen and has made them poor.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, I've been hearing about each other accusing each other in the Adriatic for decades. Basically, of course, we are very dissatisfied with what Italian fishermen have been doing for decades, and now in the northern Adriatic of course there is a big crowd, because we also have Slovenian fishermen and Croatian fishermen and Italian fishermen, and the fish are small, the shellfish is small, the sea is small, and the demand for fish is very high.  That is why I support this report because it speaks of these problems in a very clear and open way, on delicate topics, because fishermen are, of course, our big concern and I am definitely sure that a single fishing policy, and on the other hand what we want to do when we talk about fisheries control, is the right way. We have to protect the fishermen, but we also have to protect the fish so those same fishermen can do their jobs for a long time.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President, Commissioner Vella, I believe that this topic is very important because the Common Fisheries Policy certainly needs to define the sustainable development of fisheries in the European Union and especially those Member States that possess this wealth, but also tradition.  This is where I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in fact, under this common fisheries policy, we must not forget that it should in some way be and aim at having parts that are oriented towards traditional fisheries, which are currently not recognised in this common fisheries policy. There are certain categories of our fishermen who are threatened by this one common solution because it actually represents their livelihood, that is, the existence of their families.  That is why I believe that one common platform on which to build control is certainly welcome, but that the specificities of individual Member States that are already traditionally fisheries oriented should also be taken into account.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to ensure effective control of fishing activities in order to ensure the sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources and to maintain a level playing field between the European Union fleets. Unfortunately, it should be pointed out that the differences in the scope of controls and the places where they are carried out actually have discriminatory effects in relation to controls. In some Member States there are controls from vessel to table, in others only a few links in the chain are checked, excluding, for example, the transport of catches or catering. There are too many provisions on the control of fishing activities, to the extent that some of them are even contradictory, just as there are too many derogations and exceptions. It would therefore be desirable to simplify and review Regulation 1224, in order to establish a Community control system to ensure compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy and to improve the implementation of the rules in the various Member States, first and foremost by promoting greater harmonisation of the rules. Congratulations to the rapporteur, Isabelle Thomas.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: "Mr. President, speaking to fishermen, I often hear them complain that their occupation is controlled more than any other. Also, in some Member States fisheries controls are much stricter than neighbouring Member States.  Some Member States carry out controls starting from fishing gear to consumption, while others focus only on some parts of the supply chain. Consumers have the right to information on the origin of food. I therefore consider that an appropriate control system would improve the traceability of fishery products and increase the level of consumer confidence. Due to a sense of injustice, it is necessary to harmonise fisheries controls within the European Union, respecting the interests and competences of individual Member States. The present sense of injustice in the fisheries sector would be reduced by simplifying and improving Union legislation and reducing the existing administrative burden.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we greatly appreciate the report by Isabelle Thomas and the work of the rapporteur, the shadows and their teams. Effective fisheries control is indispensable if we want to improve the governance of the oceans and we, the European Union, can only make a credible case for effective controls outside the EU if our own record is clean. Therefore the Commission is now evaluating the regulation on control of fisheries for assessing its implementation and the impact on the common fisheries policy five years after its entry into force. This makes the report very well timed and useful, as it complements the work carried out by the Commission. The findings and recommendations of the report will feed into our own work and will be taken into consideration in conceiving the next actions needed for improving the current system of control of fisheries. The regulation on control of fisheries, which entered into force in 2010, changed significantly the previous control system, introducing the use of new technologies, a new management system and new principles and obligations. Thanks to this reform, the fishery control system has improved, and this has led to an overall increase in compliance with the common fisheries policy. However, if some good results have been achieved, still more should be done. Preliminary assessment of the regulation on control of fisheries shows that, while there is a good legal framework, improvements can be made, particularly on its implementation by the Member States. In brief, the report stresses that the different implementation in the Member States and their diverse commitment in its application hinder – as was said by a number of speakers – the level playing field among operators and therefore their confidence in the system and respect of the rules. The implementation by Member States greatly differs in the sanctioning system and control procedures and methods in the management of control, the training of inspectors, technologies and tools used, IT development and data sharing and exchange. All these have been noted. The principles embedded in the report go very much in the same direction as the Commission’s policy. We all recognise that having a uniform and harmonised control system of fisheries contributes to ensuring a level playing field of operators across Europe. This is important, not only in terms of treatment, but in the very end fundamental for ensuring sustainable fishing. Compliance with the common fisheries policy (CFP) cannot be achieved without awareness and support from fishermen and, in order to achieve this, we need to have their trust and cooperation. We agree with the report on the importance of continuing to fight illegal fishing and to strengthen the quality, completeness and reliability of catch data. We also agree on the underlying need to strengthen collaboration between Member States themselves and also between Member States, the Commission and the European Fisheries Control Agency, including the need to share control data in real time. The contribution of the European Fisheries Control Agency to the level playing field in the control of fisheries is critical. Their activities and operational coordination, development of standards and training are greatly appreciated by all stakeholders. Compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy is improving. Its enforcement relies on a comprehensive and sound control system with dissuasive, proportionate and effective sanctions applied by Member States. So effective actions by Member States remain essential. Let me thank you once again for this report and the fruitful discussion. We look forward to further working with the Parliament in a good spirit of cooperation.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – This report was drafted in preparation of the forthcoming Control Regulation. In brief it could be said that controls are part of the regulatory conditions under which the exploitation of the fish resources may be conducted. Therefore it is important to ensure effective controls of fisheries activities in order to guarantee sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and maintain a level playing field among EU fleets. In that context Member States should ensure effective implementation of the Control Regulation. As we know the significant improvement in the control regime has been made thanks to the current legislation in force. That not only proves that European regulations make sense but also are crucial in combating degradation of our environment. There is one point I truly want to underline: controls should not be intended as a measure where fishers are treated as criminals. The prime function of controls should be to increase compliance to agreed management measures by increasing deterrence and voluntary compliance and thus decreasing violations. A balance between enforcement and voluntary compliance should be achieved for each fishery. Participatory management involving fishers and other interested parties is a key tool required by all fisheries (artisanal, small-scale and commercial) in order to ensure an increase in compliance.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Tomasz Piotr Poręba, on behalf of the Committee on Transport, on improving connectivity and accessibility of transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe (2015/2347(INI)) (A8-0282/2016).

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am very pleased, I am very pleased that today, here in the European Parliament, I can present a report on increasing the communication accessibility of Central and Eastern Europe. I think that everyone, as we are sitting here in this House, will agree that if, in recent years, there has been no doubt, political integration in the European Union, then this integration at transport level still requires a great deal of effort and leaves a great deal to be desired. This report deals precisely with this, positions, and points out the most strategic transport links: road, rail, air, which in the coming years the European Union and the Member States on its eastern flank should build and in which European funds should be invested.  But someone will ask the question, what should be the main idea of this EU project, what directions should be taken into account in a special way? Well, in my opinion, the eastern flank requires a strong investment in transport in the north-south directions. This is a strategic direction on which we should focus in a special way. Because what is it about increasing communication accessibility? I think that each of you knows – research, various analyses, reports – that it is an increase in competitiveness, that it is an influx of foreign investment, that it is an increase, dear you, a sense of security, as the Commissioners of the European Union have also mentioned very often in my discussions. Yes, a sense of security on the eastern flank of the European Union, because a better connected, well-organised network of connections, a well-connected eastern Europe is a safer Europe. What are the most important transport routes we should invest in in the coming years, and I have allowed myself to be presented in my report? Without a doubt, dear ones, it is the Rail Baltica and Via Baltica route, connecting the Baltic States, through Poland, with the south-west of Europe. Certainly Via Carpatia – a project that both I and many of my colleagues have been seeking over the last years. This is a key project for the people of the eastern flank of the European Union, a project that has the potential to accelerate its development, a project that has the potential to give a sense of security to the people of Eastern Europe, including Polish, including my region of Subcarpathia. Residents of Rzeszów, Niska, Stalowa Wola, Barwinka, Krosna are waiting for this road. Without this path, it will not be possible to level the playing field – we will not come, we will not join western Europe without this road, without the Via Carpatia road.  But in my report, I also point out important, important river connections, the clearing of connections between the Elbe, the Oder and the Danube, between the Danube and the Rhine, and I point out the important, important, future freight directions needed for investment: the Amber Route, the eleventh route, which has every opportunity to improve development and development, trade between Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. These are, dear ones, those provisions that are included in this report and which, as I said, are strategic and such a very, very, thoughtful format agreed in large part also between the political groups and with the European Commission.  Finally, Dear Ones, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteurs from other political groups who have worked with me on this report. I am very pleased with this cooperation. I think that together we have achieved an excellent result in the form of this report, which I repeat has the opportunity to be a strategic document for the future for the European Union in terms of the development of transport in its eastern part.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other shadows for the very fruitful cooperation during the preparation of the report. It was evident from the beginning that despite the different political and geographical backgrounds, everybody was focusing on the interests of the CEE region.  The transport infrastructure in Central and Eastern Europe has undergone substantial modernisation with the help of the EU since the accession of the new Member States. Now it is obvious that we need a further boost to improve cross-border connectivity along the north-south direction in order to facilitate job creation and provide economic growth throughout the region, with special attention to projects such as Rail Baltica or Via Carpatia.  Creating viable transport ties will additionally contribute to sustainability and security along the outer borders of the EU towards the east and towards the Western Balkans as well. Finally, it is also essential to exploit synergies in funding between the different financial instruments of the European Union without losing sight of the principle of sustainability.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the TEN-T guidelines of a connecting europe mechanism, the foundations have been laid for the implementation of EU transport infrastructure policy for the period 2020-2030. The Member States of the European Union will therefore have to cooperate successfully in order to finalte the central strategic network by 2030 and the global network by 2050. However, serious gaps persist in terms of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure throughout the Central and Eastern European Union, and it is important to resolve this problem quickly, particularly in rural areas and border regions, thus trying to stem the progressive decline in population. I believe that sustainable transport links must be seen as a factor in promoting the security and stability of the European Union's eastern border and the Western Balkans. In order to achieve the TEN-T objectives, the missing connections must be built and, consequently, obstacles for passengers and goods removed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Poręba, on his proposal. Transport is a key pillar of our economy, contributing EUR 548 billion and securing more than 11 million jobs. At the same time, however, transport accounts for 25% of greenhouse gas emissions, with more than 70% coming from road transport. For this reason, the European Union is now being driven by alternative transport, public transport and in particular rail. Strengthening rail transport will bring about a significant reduction in climate impacts, air pollution and road accidents. According to the latest statistics, more than 26,000 people died on Europe's roads last year, an increase for the first time since 2001. Therefore, in addition to creating new infrastructure, the European Union should invest in modernising, completing existing infrastructure and strengthening controls in order to reduce road accidents, as well as taking measures to support road transport and hauliers.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr If, instead of travelling here from Sweden, I came by train from my other hometown, Sarajevo in Bosnia, this trip would take 48 hours. I am very grateful that I am a Swedish parliamentarian. It's extremely much easier to be. This is, of course, unreasonable. A lack of rail and road links has created major – huge – communication problems in Eastern Europe, hindering economic development, damaging jobs, reducing the movement of goods, services and people and damaging tourism, creating problems with energy supply and worsening the climate problem. That is why we need to do something about it. I am very pleased that the Commission has already proposed a package, which is just to be welcomed. But I hope that there will be more and hope that the efforts will be made quickly and that the money will eventually increase, so that enlargement in Eastern Europe will be more extensive and that the follow-up takes place often enough, so that travel in the region no longer feels like an absurdity.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President, I take the opportunity to thank the rapporteur for really highlighting in his report a very important topic that is very important for all Member States and their citizens, which is transport and transport infrastructure. In particular, he underlined the importance of regional rail, i.e. connectivity between the Member States that is currently lacking and which is actually very important not only for transport, but for the development of entrepreneurship and the economy, i.e. economic cooperation, cross-border cooperation between these countries.  I would also like to thank that he also included in his report that the EuroVelo cycling network should be strengthened, which is also a good alternative, i.e. a sequence towards sustainable transport.  Tying myself to this railway infrastructure, here I would look back at that interrail map that should be shared with young people for their 18th birthday so that they can travel through Europe for free and I believe that this is exactly what will show that young people in Southeast Europe do not really have the opportunity to travel by rail because the railway practically exists, but the 19th century railway.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, central and eastern European transport connectivity is one of the biggest infrastructure challenges facing the European Union today.  Decades of neglect of key transport infrastructure in former communist states, as well as the lack of strategic planning in their transport connections with neighbours due to the isolationist nature of former regimes, have left a mark that we must erase if we want a uniform development of the entire European Union. Colleague Poreba did a great job with this report and showed how this home can lead processes that will lead to better connecting of Member States and easier flow of people and goods. Without this, after all, we will never be able to exploit all the potential of the single market, so this report is also extremely important in this context. I especially welcome the recommendation on the inclusion of the Croatian port of Rijeka in the Baltic-Adriatic corridor. I hope that the Commission will recognise the importance of such a move, which is of particular interest to both Croatia and the European Union.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, central and eastern European countries face similar transport problems to other European Union countries, only these problems are even more difficult. This means neglect of rail traffic, neglect of river traffic, especially when it is remembered that the Danube passes through Eastern Europe and that one of the corridors of the Rhine-Danube passes through Eastern Europe. Not to mention that almost no airport has a connection to the rail network. That is why I called on countries to work better together and for the Commission to in some way encourage them to work better together to bridge their differences and thus make Europe better connected. The importance of this report is that it continues to the countries of the Western Balkans that have become part of this network, and their connection will be transport connectivity, which will mean better connectivity with Europe and a better understanding of each other.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I will not talk about big topics, I will talk and thank you for accepting the amendment of Mr. Radoš and me, and in this way potentially now the Port of Rijeka has become part of the TEN-T network. This is something that is of utmost importance for transport in the northern Adriatic.  I want to talk about one small detail because these TEN-T networks end up somewhere and sometimes twenty, fifty kilometers solve the historical problem and that is why I want to emphasize the problem of isolation in the railway traffic of the city of Pula and the Istrian peninsula, where Croatian railways enter Slovenian railways and have no direct contact, are not territorially linked. Pula has a plan to create a sea passenger terminal, it has a railway port – ideal intermodal traffic can be created at the moment if we include a railway line in the TEN-T network, and it is about eighty kilometers.  So, I invite you to think about that, too, to solve this detail and then to have the entire northern Adriatic included in the TEN-T corridors.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Violeta Bulc, I would first of all like to congratulate the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and specifically the rapporteur, Mr Poręba, on taking the initiative to present this report, which highlights the importance of connectivity across the EU. The Commission has continuously promoted the improvement of physical connections between the Member States. They are crucial for fostering cohesion, for the proper functioning of the internal market and for generating economic growth and employment. This is the cornerstone of the TEN-T policy framework renewed in 2013. The TEN-T policy and its corridors take into consideration the specific needs of Central and Eastern European states to improve their connection with the rest of Europe.  I would just mention the North Sea-Baltic Corridor that integrates the Rail Baltica project or the Rhine—Danube Corridor that emphasises the development of the Danube. We welcome the report, acknowledging the hard work of the European coordinators in developing their corridors and strongly supporting their efforts. The Commission will continue to concentrate its efforts on the effective delivery of the priorities identified in the TEN-T framework. The process of reviewing this policy framework will start in 2023 only, to allow the stability needed for the corridors to be completed. As experience shows, there is still an unequal development of transport infrastructure across the individual modes, with great priority still being given to roads when allocating national and local public funds. The Commission will therefore continue to prioritise sustainable modes of transport in line with the objectives of our Transport White Paper and our commitment to combating climate change. We acknowledge the need to continue providing funding support for the development of rail or inland waterways infrastructure in Central and Eastern European Member States. The European Union will continue to support relevant investments through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESIF) and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF). The CEF uptake in the cohesion Member States has been exemplary after the second call. Several national envelopes have already been entirely used. The third call, launched on 13 October, will be an occasion for the other cohesion Member States to fully absorb their respective allocations.  However, since the pipeline of projects is well beyond the possibilities offered by the CEF budget, we welcome the report’s call to mobilise further the key players to find additional sources of funding for key projects. We need to keep mobilising Central and Eastern European countries to fully use the potential of the opportunities offered by the Investment Plan for Europe. This is the new way forward for financing the infrastructure projects. We will thus continue to work closely with the EIB on the appropriate geographical coverage of the EFSI.  Finally, the Commission acknowledges the high complexity of the regulatory, administrative and permitting procedures entailed by the implementation of the transport projects. This particularly impacts infrastructure projects with a cross-border dimension. The Commission is therefore currently working on identifying solutions to streamline procedures and facilitate project implementation, thus generating more investment in the transport sector.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – From their accession to the present day, the transport infrastructure of the Member States in the eastern part of the Union has undoubtedly been significantly modernised and upgraded with the continued help of the EU. At the same time, for historical and geographical reasons, the focus has been on projects to rebuild connections to and from western Member States. This is to be changed and somewhat counterbalanced by the report under discussion. However, in addition to the east-west transport axis, the development of the north-south link is of the utmost importance, which can lead primarily to the economic recovery of the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe. The report is unique in its kind, as it deals with the challenges within the region and future opportunities in a single document in the field of road, rail, water and air traffic and interoperability. Hungary the fact that it raises the possibility of exploiting a number of opportunities affecting our country is also significant from the point of view of the hungarian economy. These include the further development of the Via Carpathia project and the construction of its route from north to south in the eastern part of the country, which was highlighted in the document. The report also highlights the development of relations with the candidate countries, be it Ukraine or the Western Balkan countries. The financial framework needed to achieve the ambitious targets appears to be secure.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Quality transport links are essential for promoting entrepreneurship, economic growth and related job creation. It is about improving the quality of life of our citizens. For years, for example, they have been listening to various governments about the need to complete motorway infrastructure. The situation has undoubtedly improved recently. However, this is still insufficient compared to neighbouring countries. Stronger support for better interconnection of transport networks between the V4 states, as well as throughout the Central and Eastern Europe region, is also essential. This requires intensifying cooperation and substantial investment. In addition to the Structural and Investment Funds, the European Union offers a number of financial mechanisms for this. These can be used, for example, through the European Investment Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development or the European Fund for Strategic Investments. In addition to connecting road and rail transport infrastructure or supporting local airports, the Central and Eastern European region also has significant potential in terms of water transport development.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Access to high-quality infrastructure and transport connections is not only crucial for Europe's economic development and for ensuring social, economic and territorial cohesion, but also has a major impact on the process of building the idea of a strong united European Union and a well-functioning common market. Thanks to EU funds, a great deal has changed in the countries of the new Union– transport infrastructure has been greatly modernised and the flow of goods, people and services has increased dramatically. Nevertheless, due to historical and geographical circumstances, huge differences in economic development between eastern and western Europe remain. It is therefore very important that we include in our investment plans for strengthening a modern, competitive and resource-efficient European transport system the border part of eastern Europe – especially in the context of ensuring access to modern rail and road infrastructure – which would accelerate development, increase the investment attractiveness of the area, reduce unemployment in the area and strengthen border security.  I therefore ask the European Commission to include Central and Eastern Europe more in its plans for the future transport policy.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. – The TEN-T trans-European transport network provides basic infrastructure to stimulate European tourism. The development of tourism in Europe depends mainly on the capacity of Member States to invest in infrastructure and in creating secure and safe transport for their tourists. For Bulgaria, the development of railway and road infrastructure and the promotion of multimodal transport are key to the development of tourism. Building intermodal transport to reach tourist destinations will create easier access to more sites and help a more diverse target group of tourists. It is important to target smart investments based on realistic funding opportunities.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The report on the state of infrastructure and connectivity in Central and Eastern Europe is an important step towards improving the transport system at European level, recognising that there is a significant gap between the east and west of the continent. This is a wake-up call about the effects that these development differences have on the economy of the whole Union and on the future of cohesion policies. Representing half of Europe, eastern countries need the technical and financial support of the European executive to facilitate the implementation of infrastructure plans. That is why the Commission must come up with a clear strategy for Central and Eastern Europe that integrates large infrastructure plans, taking into account both the disparities from one region to another and the need for better cooperation between national authorities and the brussels institutions. The European Parliament expresses its support for such a strategy and recommends the creation of a budget line for Eastern European infrastructure and to increase administrative capacity. At the same time, the appropriate use of the Structural and Cohesion Funds is necessary. Against the background of their poor absorption, I call for countries such as Romania to receive technical assistance for the development of projects and the use of financial instruments.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – High-quality transport links are fundamental to economic development in Europe and to the quality of life of European citizens. Transport infrastructure is still less developed in most regions of the central and eastern part of the EU compared to other European regions.  The coherence and accessibility of transport infrastructure in this part is one of the key ways of achieving the objectives of cohesion policy. Slovenia is also one of the countries that still has some outstanding challenges in terms of accessibility and connectivity of transport infrastructure and should focus on closing the gap.  This would not only allow for unsuadly traffic, but would also provide new business opportunities. Member States and the Commission should also ensure synergy and complementarity in the implementation of transport infrastructure projects, with a result of the need for synergy and complementarity between Connecting Europe, the European Structural and Investment Funds and the instruments of the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, in order to significantly improve their use and diversification, as these are projects requiring significant investment. At the same time, we would strengthen the economy and create new jobs.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Orphans aren't the only orphans. If the physical, mental, mental, physical integrity of a child is threatened, that child is an orphan. In this case, it must be assisted by a non-governmental or public organisation.  "Every child has the right to grow up in similar circumstances to his peers," said Father Csaba Faste, head of the St. Francis Foundation in Deva, at a conference I organised in the European Parliament in Brussels entitled "Good Practices in child protection and social services". While the operation of the social system is a competence of the Member States, there is an urgent need to take over European good practices in Romania, as they help to solve the anomalies that Hungarian civil and ecclesiastical organisations in Transylvania are struggling with. The state must be assisted, not hindered, by their noble activities.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for many people in Europe and all over the world, the company name IronFX became a synonym for fraud. The number of complaints about withdrawal issues against IronFX has escalated over this year as the cyberspace foreign exchange trading company refuses to pay clients’ deposits and profits for months. In such cases regulators will typically suspend the licence of the company until the discrepancies are corrected. Although IronFX was fined EUR 350 000 by the Cyprus Securities and Exchange Commission, it still operates, while the number of ongoing disputes and legal cases against the company continues to grow. To a previous written question regarding this case, the Commission acknowledged that it had also received several complaints and said that although it does not have investigatory powers, it had asked the Cypriot authorities for more information on the matter. Europe has already seen the results of inadequate consumer protection in the field of financial services. Unfortunately the situation for small investors on the financial market is still particularly vulnerable. Therefore I call on all the authorities concerned, at national and European level, to fully commit themselves to protecting the rights of European consumers and small investors and to launch a detailed investigation into the IronFX case.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by During the debate on women's rights, I was not allowed to speak, so I would like to remind you, as a one-minute speech as a long-time academic and doctor, that the conceived child is not part of a woman's body (as some of the representatives of the peoples of Europe say, which should not give false information to the European Parliament), once it has been scientifically proven that a new organism is formed at the time of conception with the combination of genetic material of a woman and a man. , genetically different from the mother and father, having a different DNA code and even a different color of hair, skin or blood type, and even prone to certain diseases. A child as a separate human being is not some kind of cancer that needs to be removed as life-threatening, but is a descendant of parents who have no right to decide to deprive their child's life at any stage of its development.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, colleagues and colleagues, I have repeatedly stressed the importance that the integration of the Western Balkan countries into the European Union has for these countries, but also for the European Union itself, and I am doing so now. With all the standard difficulties being resolved very slowly, the latest developments are not optimism.  It is an illegal referendum conducted in Republika Srpska, the announcement of similar referendums including one on the secession of Republika Srpska, then the non-recognition of the results of the elections from a part of the opposition in Montenegro, and of course there is no optimism or announcement of a second joint military exercise between Serbia and Russia on Serbian territory. I welcome the activities of the Commission, in particular Commissioners Hahn and High Representative Mogherini, but I also call on the Council and the European Parliament to make more political efforts to stabilise opportunities in the Western Balkans to make this space a space of peace and stability rather than a source of instability for Europe.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, on Friday, at the beginning of the tenth parliamentary term of the Galician Parliament in Santiago de Compostela, workers and workers from Isolux Corsan and the Pastor and Popular banks voiced their voice against the employment regulation processes that will leave 500 people out of work in Galicia and more than 3,400 in the Spanish State. This contradicts Mr Juncker's repeated promises in this House to reduce unemployment. We ask the European Commission and this Parliament to intervene to put an end to the abuses of businesses undergoing labour reforms and to put in place measures to put an end to these serious and unfair and totally unjustified situations that destroy employment, increase the risk of poverty and social exclusion and also increase job security. In the Spanish State at this time, one in five working people receives less than €300.

name: Marcellesi Florent (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Wallonia. Despite pressure from the European Commission, I am the voice of millions of people in Europe who do not accept trade agreements that are above democracy, our rights and the planet, as is the case with the CETA (CETA) between Europe and Canada.  In addition, I confess this, I envy Wallonia, a region where it is your Parliament that decides on CETA. Because in Spain the CETA has signed it has been a functioning government, without any democratic debate in our Congress.  In addition, a government with double standards: while signing the CETA, it declares itself incompetent to ratify the unanimous Paris Climate Agreement. It's not strange. CETA would radically increase CO2 emissions. Thus, one cannot at the same time be in favour of CETA and the climate, in favour of multinationals and people, serving markets and democracy.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, 10 000 migrant children are missing in Europe, say Europol. Many are in the hands of criminal gangs and traffickers, and it is the free movement of people that facilitates victims being moved across borders. Much more needs to be done and, of course, UKIP wants to help the vulnerable children at risk in Calais. But the pictures we initially saw of very mature—looking adults being brought into Britain really shows how little the Tories care about public feeling towards open—door immigration. Was it too much to ask to bring in actual young girls and boys, to help them and to reassure the British public? Clearly, the British Prime Minister does not want to control immigration or to have proper checks. Last year, a government report stated that nearly 100 000 children in the UK were in temporary housing after being made homeless. The Tories should put the needs of our own children first before opening the door to the rest of the world. Only UKIP will get control of our borders in a fair and ethical way.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, after Brexit, the European Union is no more than a paper tiger to which peoples and nations openly resist. The Hungarian people say "no!" to their policy of distributing migrants. The French and German peoples paralyzed the TAFTA negotiations. It is now the turn of Wallonia - three million inhabitants - to play the village of Asterix by blocking the adoption of CETA. It is blocking this agreement because it does not want the globalized and inhumane free trade it embodies. It is blocking it because it does not want multinationals to be able to attack states in a court of fifteen ultra-liberal judges who will be in their pay.  I express my support for the Walloon people who, in this case, embody the soul of European freedom. The European ogre revealed his totalitarian nature by despising his resistance and issuing him an ultimatum. Hold on, Walloon friends! Faced with the European Union, you revive the spirit of the ancient Greeks who repelled the onslaught of the Persian Empire.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 2016 could well be remembered as the year of the populist, or maybe I should say the year of the destroyer, because there is not much difference between populism, as we see it, and destruction. Brexit is an example: the motivating factor was to destroy the European Union and give the United Kingdom supposedly back its sovereignty. The result: sterling has dropped 18%; inflation on the rise; companies either leaving or planning to leave the United Kingdom; in my country, the threat to the peace process, which has been underwritten by the European institutions for so many years. The same is happening in America, with Mr Trump and his populism, talking about banning Mexicans and Islamists and building walls, appealing to the lowest common denominator.  Even here in Europe, we have it with CETA: the best trade agreement ever done, with one of the finest democracies in the world, and we cannot get through a local parliament, based again on unfounded fears. It is time to end populism.

name: Момчил Неков
text: (S&D). – Mr President, the CETA negotiations with Canada were concluded more than two years ago. During this time, the European Commission has received a clear signal from Europeans that mechanisms such as arbitral tribunals existing in their current form are not acceptable.  However, we still face the same mechanism in the same form unwanted by Europeans. With its decision last week, the Walloon Parliament proved to be the only one listening to the request of its citizens, and this is commendable.  Canada is the fifth largest producer of GMO foods in the world. In this reality of free trade, this will lead to the entry of GMO products and raw materials without the knowledge and desire of Europeans.  Canada still requires and discriminates against my fellow citizens when it comes to visas. It is irresponsible if the country, whose citizens travel visa-free throughout the European Union and who wants to deepen its relations with Europe, ties the visa-free regime to the signing of SETA.  And from this point of view, I call on the Bulgarian Prime Minister not to sign the agreement with Canada.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the occasion for this speech is yet another provocation carried out by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. In addition to constantly provoking the Bulgarian state border with illegal migrants, which we have recently found on train tracks, Mr Erdogan gave for the second time a speech directly claiming territorial claims to countries that are members of the European Union and TOA. We are talking about the Republic of Bulgaria and the Hellenic Republic.  The towns of Kardzhali and Thessaloniki, which are part of the territories of Bulgaria and Greece, were mentioned by name. Erdogan said he could not speak with his heart and did not distinguish between Edirne, Kardzhali, Thessaloniki, Skopje and other cities. This for us is an insurmountable, impossible territorial claim. We strongly object to this behaviour and wonder why other colleagues in the other groups do not condemn these direct territorial claims. This behavior of the Turkish dictator is another reason to say that Turkey has no place in the European Union because it is not a European country.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to warn the Commission of the alarming situation in some countries in the Western Balkans. The illegal referendum in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the coup attempt in Montenegro, relations between Montenegro because of the situation in Kosovo and what the opposition is doing in Kosovo, not to mention the situation in FYROM and Macedonia, respectively.  However, that's not all. We have a problem in the Western Balkans where a member of the European Union, Slovenia, at the moment for reasons known to her, is again raising the wall, the wire to Croatia, or on the Croatian-Slovenian border. Croatia has not raised a wall towards Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, has not raised a wire, neither during the last left-wing government nor intends to now, according to the latest statements we have heard from government representatives.  I wonder if the Commission is aware that this is an additional oil-to-fire spill on the so-called Western Balkans migrant route, in a completely unacceptable way.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, last week, at the CIE in Aluche in Madrid, thirty-nine people rebelled against their imprisonment. This week, dozens of people have gone on hunger strike at the CIE in Barcelona calling for their freedom.  In the IADs, living conditions are inhumane, but I don't think it's time to demand here today to put latrines in their cell so they don't have to shit and piss in bags at night; it is not time to ask that there be no sexual violence against the inmates; or don't let them die like Samba Martine did. And we're not going to do it because we don't want CIE in better condition: we just don't want CIE.  They are prisons in which people who have not committed any crime are locked up. They are simply there because they have no papers, because this Europe has decided that they have no name and that their only surname is that of 'illegal'. They are locked up for administrative misre lack; they are locked up because they did not die in the Mediterranean; because they were not deported to Turkey or because they were not returned hot in Melilla.  There is only one thing that needs to be done with CIDs: close them, forever.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good evening, Commissioner Vella, I am pleased that you are here this evening because I would like to talk about access to environmental justice, starting with a specific case. On 5 October, the administrative court of the Lombardy region declared inadmissible the appeal of the citizens' association Zibido San Giacomo against a measure authorising the construction of a well for the exploration of hydrocarbons. The court objected to the inadmissibility of the action for lack of interest and active legitimacy, challenging the occasional nature of the association and the fact that it does not appear representative of the local community. This approach takes on a rather stringent jurisprudential orientation. However, it omits any reference to the requirements of Italian law that associations must meet in order to obtain a standing before the Court. Therefore, I wonder, and I ask you, Commissioner, what space do we give to the environmental bodies that come from below and access to environmental justice in Europe is really guaranteed, because obviously in Italy, this is not the case today.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in the flood of breaking news, we should not forget the long-term challenges, so I would like to remind you that in two days, 27 October, is a day dedicated to audiovisual cultural heritage by UNESCO. This heritage is of great value to us both artistic in the case of films and historical in the case of records of the events of the 20th century. However, these materials are perishable and their protection, archiving and quality digitisation should therefore be an important priority for us. We should not forget to protect them.  We are currently in the European Parliament discussing the revision of the Audiovisual Services Directive, in which we also deal with the promotion of European works. We want to increase the representation of European production for audiovisual service providers also on demand, not just for radio and television. From 10% to 20%. We think it is our duty to set the rules so that we in Europe support and motivate creators to create quality audiovisual works that will be traditional continuing europe's rich cultural heritage.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a recent analysis by the National Observatory on the Health of The Italian Regions reveals the sad primacy of Campania as the region with the lowest life expectancy in Italy: two years less than the national average life expectancy. The main causes of this sad phenomenon are the huge spread of childhood obesity, environmental emergencies and poor investments in health care, often linked to economic inequalities between the various Italian regions. But campania also has the lowest per capita health expenditure in Italy because of an absurd criterion for allocating the national health fund based on the average age of the regional population, which rewards regions with a higher average age and severely penalises Campania, the youngest region in Italy. A real paradox. I call on the Commission to launch a permanent monitoring programme for Europe's areas at greatest risk of exclusion, involving Parliament and the competent bodies of the Member States, so as to allow the best possible coordination of all those called upon to take action for the implementation of effective integrated policies in depressed areas.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the situation in the 'hotspots' of the Aegean islands has reached the limit. Conflicts between refugees and illegal immigrants are now on the agenda. More than 14,000 refugees and illegal immigrants are currently stranded on the Aegean islands. At the same time, Turkey is supporting the operation of slave trade circuits that bring refugees not only to the Aegean islands but also to Evros, Thrace. At the recent European Council there was a complete failure to find a solution to the refugee crisis and to rid Greece of the burden of the thousands of refugees flooding every corner of the country. Of the 66,400 refugee relocations supposed to take place from Greece to European Union countries, only 5,200 have been made in the past year. Where's this going to go? When will the 6,000 relocations begin monthly? Impoverished Greece can no longer stand other refugees and illegal immigrants, cannot stand the sultan's games, does not tolerate Turkey's provocativeness, does not tolerate the indifference of Brussels and the hypocrisy of our so-called partners.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Before the illegal referendum in Bosnia, EU representatives threatened sanctions against the politicians running the referendum. Commissioners Mogherini and Hahn felt that the referendum was challenging Bosnia's sovereignty and integrity. Several Member States also condemned it. But then the referendum was held anyway, after all. And what, then, was the EU's reaction? Were there any sanctions? Were there any consequences, any punishments that have been threatened? Nothing.  The only thing that was agreed is the statement from the Council, which regrets this referendum. Regret! Like it's a detail. A misstatement. It is driving the country into division and the Council regrets it? If you threaten something and then do not implement it, you lose authority and send a signal that you can ignore what the EU says. That's exactly what's happened. The separatist wave is sweeping bosnia and threatening the country's European future, but the EU is watching.  My question to the Commissioner is: will the Commission act before it is too late?

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there is one thing for sure after today’s Downing Street meeting: there is nothing united about the Kingdom. It is potentially breaking up from inside out.  The Good Friday Agreement was voted overwhelmingly by 90% of the people of Ireland in two referendums. The Irish Government repealed Articles 2 and 3 of its Constitution, letting go of its territorial right to the north of Ireland, and the British Government fully repealed the Government of Ireland Act, which was the Act that had partitioned Ireland. As co-guarantors of the Good Friday Agreement, the two Member States – the two governments – built into the Good Friday Agreement the principle of consent.  Well, the people in the north of Ireland did not give their consent to be dragged out of the EU. Fifty-six percent of the people voted to remain and the British Government is telling us that is going to lead the process of negotiations, that it will be between it and the EU and no one else, and the rest of us will do as we are bid. I don’t think so, Theresa! What we are saying to the EU is that you have invested politically, financially and economically into the peace process in the north of Ireland; do not abandon the people of the north of Ireland or the peace process.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to read you, ladies and gentlemen, some numbers concerning an important region of Italy and Europe with which you are all familiar, Sicily: there are 780 million euros of the ERDF 2007-2013 not yet certified, 56% youth unemployment, 8,000 requests for eviction, 10,000 inhabitants who leave the island every year, 4,673 closures of commercial activities, 500 euros for a flight to Sicily from Milan , basically more than going to Japan from Milan. In order to get Sicily back on track, we would have to take seriously these numbers that I have just listed, programming in the best way and effectively using all the available resources. On the other hand, in such a situation, the proposals of the regional and national government are hilarious to say the least: the construction of the bridge over the Straits is proposed as a solution to isolation, operates at a hallucinatory cost that rather than uniting two coasts would unite, as Don Ciotti says, two cosche with a third perhaps composed of white-collar elites ready to take other economic advantage. The rights of Sicilians must be monitored and respected.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, in 1921, the Ioan Cantacuzino Institute of Serums and Vaccines, a scientific centre that played an extremely important role in the health of Romanians, was established in Bucharest. For generations, they have received immunity from disease through vaccines prepared at the Cantacuzino Institute, known and appreciated around the world. At European Union level, the Cantacuzino Institute is part of the strategic network on which Europe's prompt response to a widespread epidemic or biological weapons attack depends. Colleagues, after 95 years, the Cantacuzino Institute is dying, the causes being mismanagement, lack of interest of the current government and the interests of real estate business. I raise the issue before you because a solution must be found against a predictable disaster which, in the event of a continental pandemic, can put both Romanians and other Europeans in a hopeless situation. I feel that I would not properly honor my profession as a doctor, but neither would the specialist doctors working in Cantacuzino, if I overlooked the disaster of the dissolution of the Cantacuzino Institute. This event must be stopped in order to prevent disastrous consequences in the future, and I ask you to support me in my effort to explain to the current government the consequences of this bankruptcy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, imagine for a second a pipeline under the Eiffel Tower, or a pipeline through the Roman Colosseum. Can you imagine that? I don't. And a lot of people don't either.  Just as we can't imagine the extraction and storage of gas under doñana National Park. But Natural Gas does imagine it. And for this it has the approval of the Government of Spain, which for that gives future to former ministers of the PP and the PSOE, like the once famous Felipe González. Doñana is a World Heritage Site. And Doñana is part of the European Union's network of protected areas. Protect him, ladies and gentlemen. It is home to unique species, such as the Iberian lynx, and is key to the region's economy of 200,000 people.  From here, we call on the European institutions not to fall asleep, which every day counts, to stop doñana's illegal works, at least in a precautionary manner, until the full environmental impact report – as mandated by law – is completed and the alternatives to gas storage in the Doñana subsoil, which exist, are assessed.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. On the basis of a petition signed by more than 20 000 latvian and Estonian citizens, the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions will hold a special hearing next January, where one of the main themes will be the situation of the so-called non-citizens of Estonia and Latvia. These are people, most of whom have lived in these countries throughout their lives and even were born there.  For a quarter of a century, almost 15% of latvia's population and 8% of the Estonian population do not have the right to vote, including in elections to the European Parliament. The petition calls for an end to the injustices against these people by allowing them to vote at least in elections to the European Parliament.  The European Parliament has finally at least begun to observe the disorder at home, as the recently discussed violations of the rule of law in Hungary and Poland have set a precedent. Consequently, it is time to start a serious discussion in Europe also about the non-citizens of Latvia and Estonia.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by congratulating in the European Parliament the success of one of the best schools in Romania in the EU Code Week 2016 last week. It is about the Emanuil Gojdu National College in Oradea, of which I am also a graduate. In a single week, almost all the students of this high school, over a thousand in number, participated in the coding activities organized by the computer science department. Congratulations, dear students, congratulations, dear teachers. Code Week 2016 is an action held at European level, this year from 15-23 October. It promotes the importance of developing digital skills and coding knowledge, regardless of age. We all already know that digital skills will at some point become mandatory for anyone who wants to successfully integrate into the labour market. Together with the skills needed in the 21st century, such as initiative, analytical thinking or creativity, coding knowledge is a new literacy. I ask all fellow Members and other European politicians wholeheartedly to encourage such initiatives.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have just returned from a fact-finding mission in Turkish Kurdistan where I talked to communities living in a climate of fear and repression in Diyarbakir, Mardin and on the border with Syria. I saw the terrible state—sponsored destruction of the historic district of Sur, where dozens of young Kurds burned to death in basements. I talked to bereaved mothers in Nusaybin whose sons and daughters had perished because of the state’s attacks on its own citizens, their bodies torn apart, impossible to identify. Many are still missing. I met the distraught families of teachers whose loved ones have been sacked, intimidated and imprisoned for attending union meetings. I met democratically elected politicians – many of them women like myself – but who have been stripped of office due to trumped up charges because of their Kurdish identity and their political affiliation. I met Yazidi refugees cared for, not by the state, but by the Kurdish community, all wondering when the world will remember them.  Independent media is being silenced and shut down in Turkey, and journalists and academics arrested, tried and imprisoned. The country is in the grip of a terrible dictatorial man. Erdogan is messing with democracy because he is afraid of democracy. The June elections proved that there is a multiplicity of voices in Turkey and many of these belong to diverse ethnic groups and progressive forces. It is time for the EU to recognise the true reality of the Turkish State and demand human rights norms for everyone.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. In 2019, Romania will hold the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. This moment is an important one, because, for a period of time, my country will be able to set the European agenda. In light of the growing interest in the future of the Republic of Moldova, I reiterate my hope that 2019 will become the moment when the accession negotiations to the European Union will begin. It is not just intentions, but targets that can materialize with great effort and hard work at the level of the government and society in the Republic of Moldova. Therefore, I am pleased that the Social Democratic Party has proposed first place for the Chamber of Deputies in the parliamentary elections to be held in December a young dentist from the Republic of Moldova, coordinator of "PES activists diaspora", Mr. Veaceslav Şaramet. Through positive examples, through strong pro-European actions, we can make the lives of the citizens of Romania and the Republic of Moldova better, and the bonds that unite us are closer than ever and, why not, in the European Union.
